title: nemeton
text: Systemic forest territory analysis using Nemeton method nemeton R package integrated analysis forest ecosystems open spatial data. implements Nemeton method calculate, normalize, visualize multi-family biophysical indicators essential sustainable forest management.

title: nemeton
text: ðŸŒ³ Multi-family system: 12 indicator families (5 implemented: C, W, F, L + infrastructure) ðŸ“Š 15 sub-indicators: Carbon (C1, C2), Water (W1-W3), Soils (F1-F2), Landscape (L1-L2) + legacy â±ï¸ Temporal analysis: Multi-period datasets, change rate calculation, visualizations ðŸ“ˆ Advanced normalization: min-max, z-score, quantiles, family, reference ðŸŽ¯ Flexible aggregation: 4 methods (mean, weighted, geometric, harmonic) ðŸ—ºï¸ Rich visualizations: Maps, multi-family radar charts, temporal trends, heatmaps ðŸ”„ Integrated workflow: raw data composite indices ðŸ“¦ Production-ready: 661 tests, >70% coverage, 100% backward compatible

title: nemeton
text: R â‰¥ 4.1.0 Spatial packages: sf, terra, exactextractr Visualization: ggplot2, tidyr

title: nemeton
code: # From GitHub (development version) # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("pobsteta/nemeton")

title: nemeton
code: library(nemeton)  # Load demo dataset (136 ha, 20 forest parcels) data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Compute indicators from 4 families results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3", "F1", "F2", "L1", "L2") )  # Create family composite indices family_scores <- create_family_index(results)  # Visualize with 12-family radar chart nemeton_radar(family_scores, mode = "family")

title: nemeton
code: # Create multi-period dataset temporal <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "2015" = units_2015,     "2020" = units_2020,     "2025" = units_2025   ),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  # Calculate change rates rates <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity"),   type = "both" )  # Visualize trends plot_temporal_trend(temporal, indicator = "carbon")

title: nemeton v0.2.0 - Release Notes
text: Version 0.2.0 represents major expansion nemeton package, introducing: - Multi-family indicator framework (12 ecosystem service families) - Temporal analysis infrastructure (multi-period datasets) - 5 new indicator families 10 sub-indicators - Enhanced normalization visualization family-level analysis release transforms nemeton basic 5-indicator tool comprehensive ecosystem services assessment platform.

code: #' Calculer les indicateurs NÃ©mÃ©ton #' #' Calcule un ensemble d'indicateurs spatiaux pour des unitÃ©s forestiÃ¨res #' Ã  partir de couches gÃ©ospatiales. #' #' @param units Un objet \code{nemeton_units} ou \code{sf} reprÃ©sentant #'   les unitÃ©s d'analyse. #' @param layers Un objet \code{nemeton_layers} contenant les couches spatiales. #' @param indicators Vecteur de noms d'indicateurs Ã  calculer, ou \code{"all"} #'   pour tous les indicateurs disponibles. #' @param preprocess Logique. Si \code{TRUE}, harmonise automatiquement les CRS #'   et dÃ©coupe les couches sur l'emprise des unitÃ©s. #' @param parallel Logique. Si \code{TRUE}, utilise le backend \code{future} #'   pour le calcul parallÃ¨le. #' @param progress Logique. Afficher une barre de progression ? #' @param ... Arguments additionnels passÃ©s aux fonctions d'indicateurs. #' #' @return Un objet \code{sf} identique Ã  \code{units} avec des colonnes #'   additionnelles pour chaque indicateur calculÃ©. #' #' @details #' Les indicateurs disponibles peuvent Ãªtre listÃ©s avec \code{list_indicators()}. #' Chaque indicateur est calculÃ© indÃ©pendamment ; les erreurs pour un indicateur #' spÃ©cifique gÃ©nÃ¨rent un avertissement mais n'arrÃªtent pas le calcul des autres. #' #' Si \code{preprocess = TRUE}, la fonction vÃ©rifie la compatibilitÃ© des CRS #' entre \code{units} et chaque couche, et reprojette si nÃ©cessaire dans le CRS #' de \code{units}. #' #' @examples #' \dontrun{ #' library(nemeton) #' #' # Charger des unitÃ©s #' units <- nemeton_units(st_read("parcelles.gpkg")) #' #' # Charger des couches #' layers <- nemeton_layers( #'   rasters = list(ndvi = "ndvi.tif", dem = "dem.tif") #' ) #' #' # Calculer tous les indicateurs #' results <- nemeton_compute(units, layers) #' #' # Calculer seulement certains indicateurs #' results <- nemeton_compute( #'   units, layers, #'   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water") #' ) #' } #' #' @seealso #' \code{\link{nemeton_units}}, \code{\link{nemeton_layers}}, #' \code{\link{list_indicators}} #' #' @export nemeton_compute <- function(units, layers, indicators = "all",                             preprocess = TRUE, parallel = FALSE,                             progress = TRUE, ...) {   # Implementation }

text: Systemic forest territory analysis using Nemeton method nemeton R package integrated analysis forest ecosystems open spatial data. implements Nemeton method calculate, normalize, visualize multi-family biophysical indicators essential sustainable forest management.

text: ðŸŒ³ Multi-family system: 12 indicator families (5 implemented: C, W, F, L + infrastructure) ðŸ“Š 15 sub-indicators: Carbon (C1, C2), Water (W1-W3), Soils (F1-F2), Landscape (L1-L2) + legacy â±ï¸ Temporal analysis: Multi-period datasets, change rate calculation, visualizations ðŸ“ˆ Advanced normalization: min-max, z-score, quantiles, family, reference ðŸŽ¯ Flexible aggregation: 4 methods (mean, weighted, geometric, harmonic) ðŸ—ºï¸ Rich visualizations: Maps, multi-family radar charts, temporal trends, heatmaps ðŸ”„ Integrated workflow: raw data composite indices ðŸ“¦ Production-ready: 661 tests, >70% coverage, 100% backward compatible

title: nemeton - Home (English)
code: library(nemeton)  # Load demo dataset (136 ha, 20 forest parcels) data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Compute indicators from 4 families results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3", "F1", "F2", "L1", "L2") )  # Create family composite indices family_scores <- create_family_index(results)  # Visualize with 12-family radar chart nemeton_radar(family_scores, mode = "family")

title: nemeton - Home (English)
code: # Create multi-period dataset temporal <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "2015" = units_2015,     "2020" = units_2020,     "2025" = units_2025   ),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  # Calculate change rates rates <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity"),   type = "both" )  # Visualize trends plot_temporal_trend(temporal, indicator = "carbon")

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: La version 0.3.0 de nemeton Ã©tend le rÃ©fÃ©rentiel dâ€™indicateurs avec 4 nouvelles familles couvrant la biodiversitÃ©, la rÃ©silience aux risques, les dynamiques temporelles et les services climatiques. Cette vignette dÃ©montre lâ€™utilisation des 10 nouveaux indicateurs (B1-B3, R1-R3, T1-T2, A1-A2) et leur intÃ©gration dans des workflows multi-familles.
code: library(nemeton) library(sf) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Nous utilisons les donnÃ©es massif_demo_units avec quelques attributs synthÃ©tiques pour illustrer les nouveaux indicateurs.
code: # Charger les donnÃ©es de dÃ©monstration data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ]  # Ajouter des attributs synthÃ©tiques pour les exemples set.seed(42) units$strata <- sample(c("Emergent", "Dominant", "Intermediate", "Suppressed"),                        10, replace = TRUE) units$age_class <- sample(c("Young", "Intermediate", "Mature", "Old", "Ancient"),                           10, replace = TRUE) units$species <- sample(c("Quercus", "Fagus", "Pinus", "Abies"), 10, replace = TRUE) units$age <- sample(c(45, 80, 120, 150, 200), 10, replace = TRUE) units$height <- runif(10, 15, 30) units$density <- runif(10, 0.6, 0.95)  # CrÃ©er des zones protÃ©gÃ©es synthÃ©tiques bbox <- st_bbox(units) zone1 <- st_buffer(st_geometry(st_centroid(units[2, ])), 250) zone2 <- st_buffer(st_geometry(st_centroid(units[7, ])), 400)  protected_areas <- st_sf(   zone_id = c("ZNIEFF_001", "N2000_042"),   type = c("ZNIEFF", "Natura2000"),   geometry = c(zone1, zone2),   crs = st_crs(units) )  # CrÃ©er un corridor Ã©cologique synthÃ©tique corridor_geom <- st_linestring(cbind(   c(bbox["xmin"], bbox["xmax"]),   c(mean(c(bbox["ymin"], bbox["ymax"])), mean(c(bbox["ymin"], bbox["ymax"]))) ))  corridor <- st_sf(   corridor_id = "TVB_001",   geometry = st_sfc(corridor_geom, crs = st_crs(units)) )

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur B1 calcule le pourcentage de surface en zones de protection. InterprÃ©tation : Les parcelles avec B1 > 50% bÃ©nÃ©ficient dâ€™une protection significative.
code: result <- indicator_biodiversity_protection(   units,   protected_areas = protected_areas,   source = "local" )  summary(result$B1) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>    0.00    0.00    0.00   22.46   18.43  100.00

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur B2 mesure la diversitÃ© de Shannon Ã  travers les strates, Ã¢ges et essences.
code: result <- indicator_biodiversity_structure(   result,   strata_field = "strata",   age_class_field = "age_class",   species_field = "species",   method = "shannon",   weights = c(strata = 0.4, age = 0.3, species = 0.3) )  summary(result$B2) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>    84.0    85.0    85.5    85.5    86.0    87.0

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur B3 Ã©value la proximitÃ© aux corridors Ã©cologiques.
code: result <- indicator_biodiversity_connectivity(   result,   corridors = corridor,   distance_method = "edge",   max_distance = 3000 )  summary(result$B3) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   721.7  1323.4  1566.1  1559.2  1927.8  2242.6

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Les indicateurs de risque Ã©valuent les vulnÃ©rabilitÃ©s aux perturbations. Note: Dans cette vignette, nous simulons les valeurs. Pour un usage rÃ©el, utilisez les fonctions indicator_risk_fire(), indicator_risk_storm() et indicator_risk_drought() avec des donnÃ©es DEM et climatiques.
code: # Simulation des indicateurs de risque # (Dans un cas rÃ©el, utiliser les fonctions avec DEM et donnÃ©es climatiques) set.seed(43) result$R1 <- pmin(100, pmax(0, 40 + runif(10, -20, 30)))  # Risque incendie result$R2 <- pmin(100, pmax(0, 45 + runif(10, -25, 35)))  # VulnÃ©rabilitÃ© tempÃªte result$R3 <- pmin(100, pmax(0, 35 + runif(10, -15, 40)))  # Stress hydrique  # Les pins en pente ont plus de risque incendie result$R1[result$species == "Pinus"] <- result$R1[result$species == "Pinus"] * 1.3 result$R1 <- pmin(100, result$R1)  # Les peuplements hauts/denses ont plus de risque tempÃªte result$R2 <- result$R2 * (result$height / 22) * (result$density / 0.8) result$R2 <- pmin(100, result$R2)  summary(result[, c("R1", "R2", "R3")]) #>        R1              R2              R3                 geometry  #>  Min.   :29.15   Min.   :19.16   Min.   :20.55   POLYGON      :10   #>  1st Qu.:37.82   1st Qu.:28.72   1st Qu.:31.86   epsg:2154    : 0   #>  Median :46.24   Median :30.68   Median :47.03   +proj=lcc ...: 0   #>  Mean   :48.88   Mean   :38.88   Mean   :48.04                      #>  3rd Qu.:54.94   3rd Qu.:47.93   3rd Qu.:65.54                      #>  Max.   :82.70   Max.   :71.67   Max.   :73.04

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur T1 mesure lâ€™Ã¢ge des peuplements.
code: # Utiliser les Ã¢ges dÃ©jÃ  dÃ©finis result$T1 <- result$age  # Directement l'Ã¢ge en annÃ©es summary(result$T1) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>    45.0    80.0   100.0   113.5   150.0   200.0

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur T2 dÃ©tecte les transformations. Note: Utiliser indicator_temporal_change() avec des rasters Corine Land Cover multi-dates pour un usage rÃ©el.
code: # Simulation de taux de changement (%/an) set.seed(44) result$T2 <- runif(10, 0, 25) # Les forÃªts anciennes sont plus stables result$T2[result$T1 > 150] <- result$T2[result$T1 > 150] * 0.3 summary(result$T2) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>  0.8048  1.9630  9.1258  8.1851 12.3251 18.5854

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur A1 mesure le % de couverture arborÃ©e dans un buffer de 1km. Note: Utiliser indicator_air_coverage() avec un raster de vÃ©gÃ©tation pour un usage rÃ©el.
code: # Simulation de couverture dans buffer 1km set.seed(45) result$A1 <- runif(10, 40, 95) summary(result$A1) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   40.29   52.71   56.92   57.56   60.45   74.84

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Lâ€™indicateur A2 Ã©value la qualitÃ© de lâ€™air. Note: Utiliser indicator_air_quality() avec des donnÃ©es ATMO ou sources de pollution pour un usage rÃ©el.
code: # Simulation d'indice qualitÃ© air set.seed(46) result$A2 <- runif(10, 55, 95) summary(result$A2) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   62.37   65.76   78.55   77.23   87.91   92.94

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Normalisons tous les indicateurs et crÃ©ons les indices par famille.
code: # Normaliser tous les nouveaux indicateurs result_norm <- normalize_indicators(   result,   indicators = c("B1", "B2", "B3", "R1", "R2", "R3", "T1", "T2", "A1", "A2"),   method = "minmax" )  # CrÃ©er les indices composites par famille result_norm <- create_family_index(   result_norm,   family_codes = c("B", "R", "T", "A"),   method = "mean" )  # Afficher les indices par famille result_norm %>%   st_drop_geometry() %>%   select(parcel_id, family_B, family_R, family_T, family_A) %>%   head() #>   parcel_id family_B family_R family_T family_A #> 1       P01 39.80832 60.45303 61.29032 50.00000 #> 2       P02 68.82910 60.02550 17.62303 28.71851 #> 3       P03 49.84050 39.18232 44.71207 44.90653 #> 4       P04 29.08790 22.14935 62.47047 40.25588 #> 5       P05 24.27117 34.80352 11.29032 30.80376 #> 6       P06 55.55556 42.09048 41.69098 54.08198

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Pour les risques, utilisons la mÃ©thode â€œminâ€ (pire cas) : InterprÃ©tation : La mÃ©thode â€œminâ€ identifie le facteur limitant (risque le plus Ã©levÃ©).
code: # AgrÃ©gation conservative pour la famille Risques result_risk_min <- create_family_index(   result_norm,   family_codes = "R",   method = "min"  # Score = pire indicateur )  # Comparer mÃ©thodes "mean" vs "min" comparison <- result_norm %>%   st_drop_geometry() %>%   select(parcel_id, R1_norm, R2_norm, R3_norm, family_R) %>%   mutate(     risk_min = pmin(R1_norm, R2_norm, R3_norm)   ) %>%   head()  comparison #>   parcel_id   R1_norm   R2_norm   R3_norm family_R  risk_min #> 1       P01 28.205045  53.15405 100.00000 60.45303 28.205045 #> 2       P02 67.956914  21.54089  90.57869 60.02550 21.540886 #> 3       P03  1.120893 100.00000  16.42606 39.18232  1.120893 #> 4       P04 48.780961  17.66709   0.00000 22.14935  0.000000 #> 5       P05 12.187465  55.34306  36.88004 34.80352 12.187465 #> 6       P06 33.620254  77.29592  15.35528 42.09048 15.355282

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Visualisons le profil Ã©cosystÃ©mique dâ€™une parcelle avec les 4 nouvelles familles :
code: # Radar pour une parcelle (4 nouvelles familles) nemeton_radar(   result_norm,   unit_id = 1,   mode = "family",   title = "Profil v0.3.0 - Parcelle 1 (nouvelles familles)" )

what: Radar complet avec toutes les familles disponibles
title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Pour voir lâ€™ensemble des services Ã©cosystÃ©miques, ajoutons aussi les familles v0.2.0 existantes :
code: # Ajouter quelques indicateurs des familles existantes pour dÃ©monstration result_norm$C1 <- runif(10, 40, 90)  # Carbon biomass result_norm$W1 <- runif(10, 30, 80)  # Water network result_norm$F1 <- runif(10, 35, 85)  # Soil fertility result_norm$L1 <- runif(10, 25, 75)  # Landscape fragmentation  # Normaliser result_norm <- normalize_indicators(   result_norm,   indicators = c("C1", "W1", "F1", "L1"),   method = "minmax" )  # CrÃ©er indices familles existantes result_complete <- create_family_index(   result_norm,   family_codes = c("C", "W", "F", "L"),   method = "mean" ) # Radar complet : 8 familles nemeton_radar(   result_complete,   unit_id = 1,   mode = "family",   title = "Profil Ã©cosystÃ©mique complet - Parcelle 1 (8 familles)" )

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: La v0.3.0 introduit le mode comparaison pour visualiser plusieurs parcelles simultanÃ©ment :  Utilisation : Identifiez rapidement les parcelles Ã  haute biodiversitÃ© (famille B) mais forte vulnÃ©rabilitÃ© (famille R).
code: # Comparer 3 parcelles sur le mÃªme radar nemeton_radar(   result_complete,   unit_id = c(1, 5, 8),   mode = "family",   title = "Comparaison de 3 parcelles - 8 familles" )

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Identifier les forÃªts anciennes Ã  haute valeur Ã©cologique :
code: hotspots_bio <- result_complete %>%   filter(family_B > 60, T1 > 100) %>%   arrange(desc(family_B))  cat("ForÃªts anciennes Ã  haute biodiversitÃ© :", nrow(hotspots_bio), "parcelles\n") #> ForÃªts anciennes Ã  haute biodiversitÃ© : 1 parcelles  # Afficher les parcelles identifiÃ©es if(nrow(hotspots_bio) > 0) {   hotspots_bio %>%     st_drop_geometry() %>%     select(parcel_id, family_B, T1, family_R) %>%     head() } #>   parcel_id family_B  T1 family_R #> 1       P07 90.94836 150 52.78104

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: DÃ©tecter les parcelles cumulant plusieurs risques :
code: multi_risques <- result_complete %>%   mutate(     nb_risques = (R1_norm > 60) + (R2_norm > 60) + (R3_norm > 60)   ) %>%   filter(nb_risques >= 2) %>%   arrange(desc(nb_risques))  cat("Parcelles Ã  risques multiples (â‰¥2) :", nrow(multi_risques), "\n") #> Parcelles Ã  risques multiples (â‰¥2) : 1  # DÃ©tail des risques if(nrow(multi_risques) > 0) {   multi_risques %>%     st_drop_geometry() %>%     select(parcel_id, R1_norm, R2_norm, R3_norm, nb_risques, family_R) %>%     head() } #>   parcel_id  R1_norm  R2_norm  R3_norm nb_risques family_R #> 1       P02 67.95691 21.54089 90.57869          2  60.0255

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Ã‰valuer le potentiel de rÃ©gulation climatique :
code: services_climat <- result_complete %>%   filter(A1 > 70, A2 > 70) %>%   arrange(desc(family_A))  cat("Parcelles Ã  fort potentiel climatique :", nrow(services_climat), "\n") #> Parcelles Ã  fort potentiel climatique : 1  if(nrow(services_climat) > 0) {   services_climat %>%     st_drop_geometry() %>%     select(parcel_id, A1, A2, family_A) %>%     head() } #>   parcel_id       A1       A2 family_A #> 1       P08 70.51631 78.73541 70.51087

title: BiodiversitÃ©, RÃ©silience & Services Climatiques (v0.3.0)
text: Visualisons les indices composites pour les nouvelles familles :
code: library(patchwork)  p_bio <- plot_indicators_map(result_complete, indicator = "family_B",                               palette = "Greens", title = "BiodiversitÃ© (B)") p_risk <- plot_indicators_map(result_complete, indicator = "family_R",                                palette = "YlOrRd", title = "Risques (R)") p_temp <- plot_indicators_map(result_complete, indicator = "T1",                                palette = "Blues", title = "AnciennetÃ© (T1)") p_air <- plot_indicators_map(result_complete, indicator = "family_A",                               palette = "viridis", title = "Air & Climat (A)")  (p_bio + p_risk) / (p_temp + p_air)

text: La version 0.3.0 de nemeton apporte : âœ… 10 nouveaux indicateurs (B1-B3, R1-R3, T1-T2, A1-A2) âœ… 4 nouvelles familles (BiodiversitÃ©, Risques, Temps, Air) âœ… 8 familles sur 12 maintenant implÃ©mentÃ©es (avec donnÃ©es complÃ¨tes) âœ… MÃ©thode dâ€™agrÃ©gation â€œminâ€ pour analyses de risque âœ… Mode comparaison pour radars multi-parcelles âœ… 845+ tests avec 87.35% de couverture Prochaines Ã©tapes (v0.4.0) : Familles S (Social), P (Production), E (Ã‰nergie), N (NaturalitÃ©) Analyses dâ€™incertitude Monte Carlo IntÃ©gration avancÃ©e de donnÃ©es externes Ressources : Vignette â€œFamilles dâ€™indicateursâ€ : rÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet des 12 familles Vignette â€œAnalyse temporelleâ€ : workflows multi-pÃ©riodes Documentation API : ?indicator_biodiversity_protection, ?nemeton_radar, etc.

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: nemeton package implements Nemeton method systemic forest territory analysis. provides tools : Calculate 5 biophysical indicators (carbon, biodiversity, water, fragmentation, accessibility) Normalize indicator values using multiple methods Create composite indices holistic ecosystem assessment Visualize results publication-ready maps vignette demonstrates complete workflow using included massif_demo synthetic dataset.

title: Getting Started with nemeton
code: # Install from GitHub remotes::install_github("pobsteta/nemeton") library(nemeton) library(ggplot2)

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: package includes synthetic forest dataset (massif_demo) representing 5km Ã— 5km area 20 forest parcels. Forest parcels type

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Use massif_demo_layers() load associated rasters vectors: dataset includes: 4 rasters (25m resolution): biomass, DEM, land cover, species richness 2 vector layers: roads network, water courses
code: layers <- massif_demo_layers() print(layers) #>  #> â”€â”€ nemeton_layers object â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ Rasters (4) â”€â”€ #>  #> â€¢ biomass : massif_demo_biomass.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ dem : massif_demo_dem.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ landcover : massif_demo_landcover.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ species_richness : massif_demo_species_richness.tif [not loaded]  #>  #> â”€â”€ Vectors (2) â”€â”€ #>  #> â€¢ roads : massif_demo_roads.gpkg [not loaded]  #> â€¢ water : massif_demo_water.gpkg [not loaded]

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Calculate carbon stock biomass data:
code: carbon <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "carbon",   preprocess = TRUE )  summary(carbon$carbon) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   48.56   59.51   70.53   69.05   76.58  101.49

results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "all",   preprocess = TRUE,   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3)  # Land cover classes for forests )  # Inspect results names(results) #>  [1] "parcel_id"     "forest_type"   "age_class"     "management"    #>  [5] "surface_ha"    "geometry"      "carbon"        "biodiversity"  #>  [9] "water"         "fragmentation" "accessibility" # Summary of each indicator cat("
=== INDICATOR SUMMARIES ===

") #> Carbon (Mg C/parcel): print(summary(results$carbon)) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   48.56   59.51   70.53   69.05   76.58  101.49  cat("
Biodiversity (species richness):

Water regulation index:

Forest coverage (%):
") #>  #> Forest coverage (%): print(summary(results$fragmentation)) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>     100     100     100     100     100     100  cat("
Accessibility (distance to roads, m):
") #>  #> Accessibility (distance to roads, m): print(summary(results$accessibility)) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>  0.7761  0.8455  0.8964  0.9076  0.9843  1.0000

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Normalize 0-100 scale comparability:
code: normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water", "fragmentation", "accessibility"),   method = "minmax" )  # Check normalized values summary(normalized$carbon_norm) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>    0.00   20.68   41.52   38.71   52.93  100.00

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Convert accessibility â€œwildernessâ€ index (low access = high wilderness):
code: normalized <- invert_indicator(   normalized,   indicators = "accessibility_norm",   suffix = "_wilderness" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Combine multiple indicators single ecosystem health score:
code: ecosystem_health <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2),   name = "ecosystem_health" )  summary(ecosystem_health$ecosystem_health) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>   14.10   25.32   39.19   40.64   50.64   99.25

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Prioritize biodiversity wilderness:
code: conservation_value <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("biodiversity_norm", "accessibility_norm_wilderness"),   weights = c(0.6, 0.4),   name = "conservation_value" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Carbon stock distribution
code: plot_indicators_map(   results,   indicators = "carbon",   palette = "Greens",   title = "Carbon Stock Distribution",   legend_title = "Mg C/parcel" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Normalized biophysical indicators
code: plot_indicators_map(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   palette = "viridis",   facet = TRUE,   ncol = 3,   title = "Normalized Biophysical Indicators (0-100)" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Ecosystem health index
code: plot_indicators_map(   ecosystem_health,   indicators = "ecosystem_health",   palette = "RdYlGn",   title = "Ecosystem Health Index",   legend_title = "Health Score" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Normalize new data using baseline statistics:
code: # Baseline data (e.g., from year 2020) baseline <- nemeton_compute(units_2020, layers_2020, indicators = "all") baseline_norm <- normalize_indicators(baseline, method = "minmax")  # New data (e.g., from year 2024) new_data <- nemeton_compute(units_2024, layers_2024, indicators = "all")  # Normalize using baseline min/max new_norm <- normalize_indicators(   new_data,   reference_data = baseline,   method = "minmax" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Compare two different scenarios:
code: # Current state vs. management scenario plot_comparison_map(   current_state,   managed_scenario,   indicator = "carbon",   labels = c("Current (2024)", "Managed (2050)"),   palette = "Greens" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Visualize changes time:
code: # Absolute change plot_difference_map(   baseline,   current,   indicator = "carbon",   type = "absolute",   title = "Carbon Stock Change (Mg C)" )  # Relative change (%) plot_difference_map(   baseline,   current,   indicator = "carbon",   type = "relative",   title = "Carbon Stock Change (%)" )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: Save results GeoPackage Shapefile:
code: # Export results sf::st_write(   ecosystem_health,   "results/ecosystem_health_2024.gpkg",   delete_dsn = TRUE )  # Save plots ggsave(   "figures/ecosystem_health.png",   width = 10,   height = 8,   dpi = 300 )

title: Getting Started with nemeton
text: nemeton package provides complete workflow forest ecosystem analysis: Data preparation: Load spatial units layers Indicator calculation: Compute biophysical metrics Normalization: Scale indicators comparability Aggregation: Create composite indices Visualization: Generate publication-ready maps information, see: Package documentation: help(package = "nemeton") GitHub repository: https://github.com/pobsteta/nemeton

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
text: Le package nemeton implÃ©mente la mÃ©thode Nemeton pour lâ€™analyse systÃ©mique de territoires forestiers. Il fournit des outils pour : Calculer des indicateurs biophysiques multi-famille (carbone, eau, sols, paysage, etc.) Normaliser les valeurs dâ€™indicateurs selon plusieurs mÃ©thodes CrÃ©er des indices composites pour une Ã©valuation holistique Visualiser les rÃ©sultats avec des cartes et graphiques Cette vignette dÃ©montre le workflow complet avec le jeu de donnÃ©es massif_demo.

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
code: # Depuis GitHub remotes::install_github("pobsteta/nemeton") library(nemeton) library(ggplot2)

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
text: Le package inclut un jeu de donnÃ©es synthÃ©tique (massif_demo) reprÃ©sentant une zone de 5km Ã— 5km avec 20 parcelles forestiÃ¨res. Parcelles forestiÃ¨res par type
code: # Charger les parcelles forestiÃ¨res data(massif_demo_units)  # Inspecter les parcelles print(massif_demo_units) #> Simple feature collection with 20 features and 5 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: 698041.8 ymin: 6499215 xmax: 702793.8 ymax: 6504159 #> Projected CRS: RGF93 v1 / Lambert-93 #> First 10 features: #>    parcel_id      forest_type age_class   management surface_ha #> 1        P01     Futaie mixte    Mature        Mixte   4.989211 #> 2        P02 Futaie rÃ©sineuse     Moyen   Production   5.867935 #> 3        P03  Futaie feuillue  SurannÃ©e Conservation   6.557777 #> 4        P04  Futaie feuillue  SurannÃ©e   Production   9.989553 #> 5        P05 Futaie rÃ©sineuse     Moyen   Production   5.906395 #> 6        P06 Futaie rÃ©sineuse    Mature   Production   1.048296 #> 7        P07  Futaie feuillue    Mature        Mixte  17.079363 #> 8        P08  Futaie feuillue    Mature   Production  11.414577 #> 9        P09     Futaie mixte     Moyen   Production  16.105209 #> 10       P10          Taillis  SurannÃ©e   Production  10.733433 #>                          geometry #> 1  POLYGON ((698299.9 6499928,... #> 2  POLYGON ((701702.2 6500418,... #> 3  POLYGON ((702240.4 6500270,... #> 4  POLYGON ((700641.3 6504129,... #> 5  POLYGON ((699268.2 6500307,... #> 6  POLYGON ((699943.5 6499421,... #> 7  POLYGON ((698500.5 6499360,... #> 8  POLYGON ((699061.9 6499649,... #> 9  POLYGON ((702258.5 6500666,... #> 10 POLYGON ((699897.1 6500739,...  # Statistiques sommaires cat("\nSurface totale:", sum(massif_demo_units$surface_ha), "ha\n") #>  #> Surface totale: 136.0225 ha table(massif_demo_units$forest_type) #>  #>  Futaie feuillue     Futaie mixte Futaie rÃ©sineuse          Taillis  #>               11                2                4                3 ggplot(massif_demo_units) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = forest_type)) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(title = "Massif Demo - Types forestiers",        fill = "Type de forÃªt")

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
text: Utilisez massif_demo_layers() pour charger tous les rasters et vecteurs associÃ©s : Le jeu de donnÃ©es inclut : - Rasters : biomasse, MNT, occupation du sol, richesse spÃ©cifique - Vecteurs : rÃ©seau routier, cours dâ€™eau
code: layers <- massif_demo_layers() print(layers) #>  #> â”€â”€ nemeton_layers object â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ Rasters (4) â”€â”€ #>  #> â€¢ biomass : massif_demo_biomass.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ dem : massif_demo_dem.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ landcover : massif_demo_landcover.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ species_richness : massif_demo_species_richness.tif [not loaded]  #>  #> â”€â”€ Vectors (2) â”€â”€ #>  #> â€¢ roads : massif_demo_roads.gpkg [not loaded]  #> â€¢ water : massif_demo_water.gpkg [not loaded]

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
code: # Poids personnalisÃ©s (carbone 50%, biodiversitÃ© 30%, eau 20%) composite_weighted <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2),   name = "conservation_index" )

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
code: # Moyenne gÃ©omÃ©trique (effets multiplicatifs) composite_geom <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "water_norm"),   aggregation = "geometric_mean",   name = "water_carbon_index" )  # Minimum (approche conservatrice, facteur limitant) composite_min <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm"),   aggregation = "min",   name = "minimum_performance" )

code: plot_indicators_map(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm"),   palette = "viridis",   facet = TRUE,   ncol = 2,   title = "Comparaison carbone vs biodiversitÃ©" )

code: nemeton_radar(   normalized,   unit_id = "P01",   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   title = "Profil multi-indicateurs - Parcelle P01" )

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
text: Voici un exemple de workflow complet de bout en bout :
code: # 1. Charger les donnÃ©es data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # 2. Calculer les indicateurs results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water",                  "fragmentation", "accessibility") )  # 3. Normaliser (0-100) normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water",                  "fragmentation", "accessibility"),   method = "minmax" )  # 4. CrÃ©er un indice composite composite <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2),   name = "forest_quality" )  # 5. Visualiser plot_indicators_map(   composite,   indicators = "forest_quality",   title = "Indice de qualitÃ© forestiÃ¨re",   legend_title = "Score (0-100)" )

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
text: Pour les indicateurs oÃ¹ une valeur faible est souhaitable :
code: # Exemple: inverser un indicateur # (UtilisÃ© pour les indicateurs oÃ¹ une valeur faible est souhaitable) normalized_inv <- invert_indicator(   normalized,   indicators = "water_norm",   suffix = "_inv" )  # L'indicateur inversÃ© head(normalized_inv[, c("parcel_id", "water_norm", "water_norm_inv")])

title: DÃ©marrage rapide avec nemeton
code: # SÃ©lectionner uniquement les futaies feuillues broadleaf <- normalized[normalized$forest_type == "Futaie feuillue", ]  # CrÃ©er un indice spÃ©cifique broadleaf_index <- create_composite_index(   broadleaf,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm"),   name = "broadleaf_quality" )

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: nemeton package implements comprehensive multi-family indicator framework forest ecosystem assessment, based Nemeton method developed Vivre en ForÃªt. framework organizes ecosystem services 12 distinct families, representing key dimension forest functioning.

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Overview 12 Indicator Families Version 0.2.0 implements 5 families 10 sub-indicators, providing solid foundation multi-dimensional ecosystem analysis.

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
code: # Install from GitHub remotes::install_github("pobsteta/nemeton") library(nemeton) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: radar chart illustrates complete multi-dimensional framework, showing 12 families combine provide holistic assessment forest ecosystem services. 12-Family Radar Chart - Complete Nemeton Framework Interpretation: example parcel shows: Strengths (> 75): Social value (S), Water regulation (W), Energy/Climate (E), Time/Dynamics (T) Good performance (65-75): Carbon (C), Air (), Productive (P), Biodiversity (B) Areas improvement (< 65): Naturalness (N), Resilience (R), Landscape (L) radar chart reveals multi-dimensional trade-offs inherent forest management: high productivity (P) social value (S) may come expense naturalness (N) landscape integrity (L).
code: # Load demo data data(massif_demo_units)  # Create sample family scores for demonstration (0-100 scale) # In practice, these would be computed from real indicators demo_unit <- massif_demo_units[1, ]  # Simulate family scores for all 12 families # Higher values = better performance in that dimension demo_unit$family_C <- 75  # Carbon/Vitality - Good carbon storage demo_unit$family_B <- 65  # Biodiversity - Moderate species richness demo_unit$family_W <- 82  # Water - Excellent water regulation demo_unit$family_A <- 70  # Air/Microclimate - Good air quality demo_unit$family_F <- 68  # Soil Fertility - Moderate fertility demo_unit$family_L <- 55  # Landscape - Some fragmentation demo_unit$family_T <- 78  # Time/Dynamics - Old-growth characteristics demo_unit$family_R <- 60  # Resilience/Risks - Moderate climate risk demo_unit$family_S <- 85  # Social/Uses - High recreational value demo_unit$family_P <- 72  # Productive - Good timber potential demo_unit$family_E <- 80  # Energy/Climate - Strong carbon sequestration demo_unit$family_N <- 62  # Naturalness - Moderate naturalness  # Create 12-family radar chart nemeton_radar(   demo_unit,   mode = "family",   indicators = c("family_C", "family_B", "family_W", "family_A",                  "family_F", "family_L", "family_T", "family_R",                  "family_S", "family_P", "family_E", "family_N"),   normalize = FALSE,  # Already on 0-100 scale   title = "Complete 12-Family Ecosystem Profile",   fill_color = "#2E7D32",   fill_alpha = 0.25 )

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Carbon family quantifies carbon storage vegetation vitality.

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family C: Carbon & Vitality
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Estimates aboveground biomass using allometric models BD ForÃªt v2 data. Allometric Models: Quercus (oak): Species-specific coefficients Fagus (beech): Species-specific coefficients Pinus (pine): Species-specific coefficients Abies (fir): Species-specific coefficients Generic: species Output: Tonnes carbon per hectare (tC/ha)
code: # Requires BD ForÃªt v2 with species, age, density layers <- list(   bd_foret = terra::vect("data/bd_foret_v2.gpkg") )  carbon_biomass <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "C1",   preprocess = TRUE )  summary(carbon_biomass$C1)  # tC/ha

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family C: Carbon & Vitality
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Calculates mean NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) Sentinel-2 imagery. Future Extension (v0.3.0): 5-year NDVI trend analysis vitality dynamics.
code: # Requires NDVI raster (Sentinel-2) layers <- list(   ndvi = terra::rast("data/sentinel2_ndvi.tif") )  carbon_ndvi <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "C2" )  summary(carbon_ndvi$C2)  # 0-1 scale

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Water family assesses forestâ€™s role infiltration, storage, water quality.

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family W: Water Regulation
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Measures river/stream length per hectare.
code: # Requires hydrographic network (SF linestring) layers <- list(   rivers = sf::st_read("data/hydrographic_network.gpkg") )  water_network <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "W1" )  summary(water_network$W1)  # km/ha

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family W: Water Regulation
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Percentage parcel covered wetlands riparian zones.
code: # Requires wetland polygons (SF) layers <- list(   wetlands = sf::st_read("data/wetlands.gpkg") )  water_wetlands <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "W2" )  summary(water_wetlands$W2)  # % coverage

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family W: Water Regulation
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Calculates TWI DEM using flow accumulation slope. Note: Uses terra D8 flow algorithm default. Optional whitebox support D-infinity.
code: # Requires DEM (terra raster) layers <- list(   dem = terra::rast("data/dem_25m.tif") )  water_twi <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "W3" )  summary(water_twi$W3)  # TWI index

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Soil family evaluates soil health erosion risk.

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family F: Soil Fertility
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Classifies soil fertility BD Sol (French soil database) equivalent. Classes: High fertility (80-100) Medium fertility (40-80) Low fertility (0-40)
code: # Requires BD Sol raster with fertility classes layers <- list(   soil_fertility = terra::rast("data/bd_sol_fertility.tif") )  soil_fertility <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "F1" )  summary(soil_fertility$F1)  # 0-100 scale

previous_headings: Implemented Families (v0.2.0) > Family F: Soil Fertility
title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Combines slope vegetation cover assess erosion vulnerability. Formula: Erosion Risk = Slope (%) Ã— (1 - Vegetation Cover)
code: # Requires DEM and land cover raster layers <- list(   dem = terra::rast("data/dem_25m.tif"),   landcover = terra::rast("data/landcover.tif") )  soil_erosion <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "F2" )  summary(soil_erosion$F2)  # Risk score (higher = more risk)

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Landscape family quantifies spatial patterns connectivity.

text: Counts forest patches calculates mean patch size.
code: # Requires land cover raster layers <- list(   landcover = terra::rast("data/landcover.tif") )  landscape_frag <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "L1",   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3)  # Forest classes )  summary(landscape_frag$L1)  # Patch count

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Calculates forest edge density (m/ha). Interpretation: Higher values indicate fragmented landscapes.
code: landscape_edge <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "L2",   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3) )  summary(landscape_edge$L2)  # m/ha

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
code: # Load demo data and layers data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Compute indicators from 4 families (C, W, F, L) results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units[1:10, ],   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3", "F1", "F2", "L1", "L2"),   preprocess = TRUE )  # Check results names(results)

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Normalize indicators independently within family:
code: # Family-aware normalization normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "minmax",   by_family = TRUE  # Normalize C1/C2 together, W1/W2/W3 together, etc. )  # All indicators now on 0-100 scale within families summary(normalized$C1) summary(normalized$W1)

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Aggregate indicators family-level scores: Aggregation Methods: method = "mean": Simple average method = "weighted": Weighted average (custom weights) method = "geometric": Geometric mean (penalizes low values) method = "harmonic": Harmonic mean (emphasizes balance)
code: # Create family composite scores family_scores <- create_family_index(   normalized,   method = "weighted",   weights = list(     C = c(C1 = 0.6, C2 = 0.4),      # Prioritize biomass     W = c(W1 = 0.3, W2 = 0.3, W3 = 0.4),  # TWI most important     F = c(F1 = 0.7, F2 = 0.3),      # Fertility > erosion     L = c(L1 = 0.5, L2 = 0.5)       # Equal weights   ) )  # Check family scores names(family_scores) # Contains: family_C, family_W, family_F, family_L + original indicators

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: radar plot displays 4 axes (one per family: C, W, F, L), showing ecosystem service profile glance. Future (v0.3.0+): Expand 12 axes families implemented.
code: # Multi-family radar plot nemeton_radar(   family_scores,   unit_id = 1,   mode = "family",           # Use family scores   title = "Parcel P001: Multi-Family Profile" )

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide

library(nemeton)  # ============================================================================ # STEP 1: Load Data # ============================================================================  data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Select 10 parcels for analysis units <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ] units$parcel_id <- paste0("P", sprintf("%03d", 1:10))  # ============================================================================ # STEP 2: Compute Multi-Family Indicators # ============================================================================  # Compute all available indicators (v0.2.0) results <- nemeton_compute(   units,   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3", "F1", "F2", "L1", "L2"),   preprocess = TRUE )  # ============================================================================ # STEP 3: Normalize by Family # ============================================================================  normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "minmax",   by_family = TRUE )  # ============================================================================ # STEP 4: Create Family Indices # ============================================================================  family_scores <- create_family_index(   normalized,   method = "weighted",   weights = list(     C = c(C1 = 0.7, C2 = 0.3),     W = c(W1 = 0.25, W2 = 0.25, W3 = 0.5),     F = c(F1 = 0.6, F2 = 0.4),     L = c(L1 = 0.5, L2 = 0.5)   ) )  # ============================================================================ # STEP 5: Visualize Multi-Family Profiles # ============================================================================  # Radar plot for parcel P001 nemeton_radar(   family_scores,   unit_id = "P001",   mode = "family",   title = "Multi-Family Ecosystem Profile - Parcel P001" )  # ============================================================================ # STEP 6: Identify Strengths and Weaknesses # ============================================================================  # Extract family scores scores_table <- family_scores %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%   select(parcel_id, starts_with("family_"))  # Rank parcels by family cat("
=== Top Parcels by Family ===

Water (family_W):
") scores_table %>%   arrange(desc(family_W)) %>%   select(parcel_id, family_W) %>%   head(3) %>%   print()  # ============================================================================ # STEP 7: Export Results # ============================================================================  # Save family scores sf::st_write(   family_scores,   "results/family_scores_2025.gpkg",   delete_dsn = TRUE )  # Export CSV table write.csv(   scores_table,   "results/family_scores_2025.csv",   row.names = FALSE )

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Family B - Biodiversity: B1: Protected habitat presence B2: Structural diversity (age classes, layers) B3: Ecological connectivity Family R - Resilience/Risks: R1: Fire risk (FWI, fuel load) R2: Storm risk (exposure, stand structure) R3: Drought risk (water balance, species) Family T - Time/Dynamics: T1: Forest cover ancientness T2: Land use change analysis Family N - Naturalness: N1: Distance infrastructure N2: Continuous forest cover N3: Composite naturalness index

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Family S - Social/Uses: S1: Trail density S2: Accessibility (distance roads) S3: Proximity populations Family P - Productive/Heritage: P1: Standing timber volume P2: Forest productivity P3: Timber vs fuelwood ratio Family - Air/Microclimate: A1: Forest cover (1 km buffer) A2: Air quality (ATMO data integration) Family E - Energy/Climate: E1: Fuelwood potential E2: Carbon emission avoidance (substitution)

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: can define custom aggregation methods modifying create_family_index():
code: # Example: Min-max aggregation (most pessimistic) custom_aggregate <- function(indicators) {   # Return the minimum value within family   min(indicators, na.rm = TRUE) }  # Would require extending create_family_index() to accept custom functions

title: Indicator Families Reference Guide
text: Combine family indices temporal analysis: See vignette("temporal-analysis") details.
code: # Compute family scores for each period family_2015 <- create_family_index(results_2015) family_2020 <- create_family_index(results_2020) family_2025 <- create_family_index(results_2025)  # Create temporal object temporal_families <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "2015" = family_2015,     "2020" = family_2020,     "2025" = family_2025   ),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  # Calculate family score change rates family_rates <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_families,   indicators = c("family_C", "family_W", "family_F", "family_L"),   type = "both" )  # Which family is improving fastest?

Cette vignette prÃ©sente le rÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet et dÃ©montre lâ€™utilisation du systÃ¨me de familles.

title: Familles d'indicateurs - RÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet
text: Le package utilise un systÃ¨me de prÃ©fixes de famille pour organiser les indicateurs :
code: # Les indicateurs bruts suivent le pattern : famille_nom # Exemples : carbon_biomass    # Famille C water_network     # Famille W soil_fertility    # Famille F  # Les indicateurs normalisÃ©s ajoutent le suffixe _norm : carbon_biomass_norm water_network_norm

title: Familles d'indicateurs - RÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet
code: # DÃ©tecter la famille d'un indicateur detect_indicator_family("carbon_biomass") # [1] "C"  detect_indicator_family("water_twi_norm") # [1] "W"  # Obtenir le nom complet de la famille get_family_name("C") # [1] "Carbone & VitalitÃ©"  get_family_name("W", lang = "en") # [1] "Water Regulation"

title: Familles d'indicateurs - RÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet
text: Normalisez tous les indicateurs dâ€™une ou plusieurs familles :
code: # Charger les donnÃ©es data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Calculer indicateurs des familles C et W results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = c("carbon", "water", "biodiversity") )  # Normaliser tous les indicateurs normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "water", "biodiversity"),   method = "minmax" )  # Les colonnes normalisÃ©es ont le suffixe _norm names(normalized)

title: Familles d'indicateurs - RÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet
text: CrÃ©ez des indices agrÃ©gÃ©s par famille avec create_family_index() : Fonctionnement : - DÃ©tecte automatiquement les indicateurs de la famille (prÃ©fixe) - AgrÃ¨ge par moyenne arithmÃ©tique (par dÃ©faut) - CrÃ©e une nouvelle colonne avec le nom spÃ©cifiÃ©
code: # Exemple fictif (nÃ©cessite indicateurs C1 et C2) # Indice famille C (Carbone) score_carbon <- create_family_index(   normalized,   family = "C",   name = "score_carbon" )  # Indice famille W (Eau) score_water <- create_family_index(   normalized,   family = "W",   name = "score_water" )

code: # CrÃ©er scores pour chaque famille families <- c("C", "W", "F", "L") for (fam in families) {   normalized <- create_family_index(     normalized,     family = fam,     name = paste0("score_", tolower(fam))   ) }  # Radar avec 4 familles nemeton_radar(   normalized,   unit_id = "P01",   indicators = c("score_c", "score_w", "score_f", "score_l"),   title = "Profil multi-famille - Parcelle P01" )

title: Familles d'indicateurs - RÃ©fÃ©rentiel complet
code: # 1. Charger donnÃ©es data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # 2. Calculer indicateurs de 3 familles results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = c(     "carbon",        # Famille C     "water",         # Famille W     "biodiversity"   # Famille B   ) )  # 3. Normaliser normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "water", "biodiversity"),   method = "minmax" )  # 4. CrÃ©er indices par famille normalized <- create_family_index(normalized, family = "C", name = "score_carbon") normalized <- create_family_index(normalized, family = "W", name = "score_water") normalized <- create_family_index(normalized, family = "B", name = "score_bio")  # 5. Indice global multi-famille global_index <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("score_carbon", "score_water", "score_bio"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.3),   name = "ecosystem_services_index" )  # 6. Visualisation plot_indicators_map(   global_index,   indicators = "ecosystem_services_index",   palette = "RdYlGn",   title = "Indice global de services Ã©cosystÃ©miques",   legend_title = "Score (0-100)" )

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Le package nemeton supporte nativement le franÃ§ais et lâ€™anglais pour tous les messages, erreurs et documentations. Cette vignette explique comment utiliser le systÃ¨me dâ€™internationalisation (i18n).
code: library(nemeton)

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Par dÃ©faut, le package dÃ©tecte la langue du systÃ¨me :
code: # Afficher la langue actuelle Sys.getenv("LANG") #> [1] "fr_FR.UTF-8"

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Utilisez nemeton_set_language() pour dÃ©finir explicitement la langue :
code: # Passer en franÃ§ais nemeton_set_language("fr")  # Switch to English nemeton_set_language("en")

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
code: # La langue est stockÃ©e dans une option getOption("nemeton.lang") # [1] "fr"  ou "en"

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Les messages dâ€™information, dâ€™avertissement et dâ€™erreur sâ€™affichent dans la langue dÃ©finie.

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
code: nemeton_set_language("fr")  # Erreur si donnÃ©es manquantes nemeton_compute(NULL, NULL, "carbon") # Erreur : Les donnÃ©es 'data' doivent Ãªtre un objet sf

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
code: nemeton_set_language("en")  # Error with missing data nemeton_compute(NULL, NULL, "carbon") # Error: 'data' must be an sf object

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Le systÃ¨me i18n couvre : Erreurs de validation : Types de donnÃ©es, paramÃ¨tres manquants Avertissements : Indicateurs manquants, valeurs atypiques Messages dâ€™information : Progression des calculs, rÃ©sultats Noms de familles : Labels pour les 12 familles dâ€™indicateurs

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
code: # En franÃ§ais nemeton_set_language("fr") get_family_name("C") # [1] "Carbone & VitalitÃ©"  get_family_name("W") # [1] "Eau"  # In English nemeton_set_language("en") get_family_name("C") # [1] "Carbon & Vitality"  get_family_name("W") # [1] "Water Regulation"

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: La langue dÃ©finie reste active pour toute la session R :
code: # DÃ©finir le franÃ§ais au dÃ©but du script nemeton_set_language("fr")  # Tous les appels suivants utilisent le franÃ§ais results <- nemeton_compute(...) normalized <- normalize_indicators(...) plot_indicators_map(...)

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: La documentation des fonctions (help) est en anglais (standard R), avec des exemples en franÃ§ais dans les vignettes.
code: ?nemeton_compute ?plot_indicators_map

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Les vignettes sont disponibles en franÃ§ais : vignette("getting-started_fr") - DÃ©marrage rapide vignette("indicator-families_fr") - Familles dâ€™indicateurs vignette("temporal-analysis_fr") - Analyse temporelle

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Le systÃ¨me i18n utilise des fichiers de traduction dans R/i18n.R.

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
code: # Exemple de structure interne messages <- list(   fr = list(     error_no_data = "Les donnÃ©es 'data' doivent Ãªtre un objet sf",     info_computing = "Calcul de {n} indicateurs..."   ),   en = list(     error_no_data = "'data' must be an sf object",     info_computing = "Computing {n} indicators..."   ) )

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Pour contribuer une nouvelle langue : CrÃ©er une nouvelle section dans R/i18n.R Traduire tous les messages Mettre Ã  jour nemeton_set_language() pour supporter le nouveau code langue Soumettre une Pull Request

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
code: # ===== VERSION FRANÃ‡AISE ===== nemeton_set_language("fr")  data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "carbon" ) # â„¹ Calcul de 1 indicateurs... # âœ” 1/1 indicateurs calculÃ©s  plot_indicators_map(   results,   indicators = "carbon",   title = "Stock de carbone",   legend_title = "Mg C/parcel" )  # ===== ENGLISH VERSION ===== nemeton_set_language("en")  data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "carbon" ) # â„¹ Computing 1 indicators... # âœ” 1/1 indicators computed  plot_indicators_map(   results,   indicators = "carbon",   title = "Carbon Stock",   legend_title = "Mg C/parcel" )

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: DÃ©finir la langue une seule fois au dÃ©but du script Documenter la langue utilisÃ©e dans vos analyses Utiliser les noms de familles localisÃ©s avec get_family_name() Tester les deux langues si vous partagez du code international

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Documentation R : Aide des fonctions uniquement en anglais (standard CRAN) Noms de colonnes : Identifiants techniques toujours en anglais (ex: carbon_norm) Palettes et thÃ¨mes : Labels graphiques dÃ©finis par lâ€™utilisateur

title: Internationalisation (i18n)
text: Versions futures : - Support additionnel : Espagnol, Italien, Allemand - Traduction automatique des labels de graphiques - Templates de rapports multilingues

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: nemeton package provides comprehensive tools temporal analysis forest ecosystem indicators. vignette demonstrates : Manage multi-period datasets nemeton_temporal() Calculate change rates (absolute relative) calculate_change_rate() Visualize temporal trends time-series plots Create heatmaps indicator evolution Compare /intervention scenarios Temporal analysis enables forest managers : Detect trends: Identify long-term changes ecosystem services Assess interventions: Evaluate impact management actions Monitor resilience: Track recovery disturbances Inform decisions: Base strategies observed dynamics

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
code: # Install from GitHub remotes::install_github("pobsteta/nemeton") library(nemeton) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr)

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: nemeton_temporal object contains multiple time periods, spatial units tracked time.
code: # Load demo data data(massif_demo_units)  # Simulate three time periods (2015, 2020, 2025) # In practice, these would come from different data sources  # Period 1: 2015 baseline units_2015 <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ] units_2015$period <- "2015" units_2015$parcel_id <- paste0("P", sprintf("%03d", 1:10)) units_2015$carbon <- rnorm(10, mean = 150, sd = 20) units_2015$biodiversity <- rnorm(10, mean = 12, sd = 3) units_2015$water <- rnorm(10, mean = 8, sd = 2)  # Period 2: 2020 intermediate (some growth) units_2020 <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ] units_2020$period <- "2020" units_2020$parcel_id <- paste0("P", sprintf("%03d", 1:10)) units_2020$carbon <- units_2015$carbon * runif(10, 1.05, 1.15)  # 5-15% growth units_2020$biodiversity <- units_2015$biodiversity + rnorm(10, mean = 1, sd = 0.5) units_2020$water <- units_2015$water + rnorm(10, mean = 0, sd = 0.3)  # Period 3: 2025 recent (continued growth + intervention effects) units_2025 <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ] units_2025$period <- "2025" units_2025$parcel_id <- paste0("P", sprintf("%03d", 1:10)) units_2025$carbon <- units_2020$carbon * runif(10, 1.08, 1.20) units_2025$biodiversity <- units_2020$biodiversity + rnorm(10, mean = 1.5, sd = 0.8) units_2025$water <- units_2020$water + rnorm(10, mean = 0.5, sd = 0.4)

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: temporal object tracks: 3 periods (2015, 2020, 2025) 10 spatial units (parcels P001-P010) 3 indicators (carbon, biodiversity, water) Consistent identifiers across time (parcel_id)
code: # Create temporal dataset temporal_data <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "2015" = units_2015,     "2020" = units_2020,     "2025" = units_2025   ),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  # Inspect temporal object print(temporal_data) #> nemeton_temporal object #>   3 periods: 2015, 2020, 2025 #>   10 units tracked across periods #>   Date range: 2015-01-01 to 2025-01-01 #>   Indicators: surface_ha, carbon, biodiversity, water # Summary statistics summary(temporal_data) #> nemeton_temporal object #>   3 periods: 2015, 2020, 2025 #>   10 units tracked across periods #>   Date range: 2015-01-01 to 2025-01-01 #>   Indicators: surface_ha, carbon, biodiversity, water #>  #> Period summaries: #>  #>   Period 1: 2015 (2015) #>     Units: 10 #>     Indicator ranges: #>       surface_ha: [1.05, 17.08] (mean: 8.97) #>       carbon: [101.25, 172.97] (mean: 141.17) #>       biodiversity: [6.41, 18.20] (mean: 11.46) #>       water: [4.98, 11.78] (mean: 7.75) #>  #>   Period 2: 2020 (2020) #>     Units: 10 #>     Indicator ranges: #>       surface_ha: [1.05, 17.08] (mean: 8.97) #>       carbon: [112.09, 184.93] (mean: 155.10) #>       biodiversity: [7.45, 19.06] (mean: 12.36) #>       water: [4.98, 11.20] (mean: 7.81) #>  #>   Period 3: 2025 (2025) #>     Units: 10 #>     Indicator ranges: #>       surface_ha: [1.05, 17.08] (mean: 8.97) #>       carbon: [121.21, 216.21] (mean: 179.80) #>       biodiversity: [8.17, 21.45] (mean: 13.79) #>       water: [5.45, 12.23] (mean: 8.43)

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Absolute change quantifies raw difference periods (e.g., Mg C/ha/year).

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Relative change expresses change percentage baseline (e.g., %/year).
code:
# Calculate relative change rates rates_relative <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_data,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   type = "relative" )  # Summary of biodiversity change (%) cat("
=== Biodiversity Change Rate (%/year) ===
") #>  #> === Biodiversity Change Rate (%/year) === summary(rates_relative$biodiversity_rate_rel) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>  0.7293  1.6053  2.1036  2.1586  2.8635  3.1841  # Identify parcels with highest biodiversity increase top_bio <- rates_relative %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%   arrange(desc(biodiversity_rate_rel)) %>%   head(3)  cat("
Top 3 parcels for biodiversity increase:
") #>  #> Top 3 parcels for biodiversity increase: print(top_bio[, c("parcel_id", "biodiversity_rate_rel")]) #>   parcel_id biodiversity_rate_rel #> 1      P001              3.184117 #> 2      P004              3.019919 #> 3      P007              2.905961

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Calculate types simultaneously:
code: # Both rate types rates_both <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_data,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   type = "both" )  # Check columns cat("\nAvailable columns:\n") #>  #> Available columns: grep("_rate_", names(rates_both), value = TRUE) #> [1] "carbon_rate_abs"       "carbon_rate_rel"       "biodiversity_rate_abs" #> [4] "biodiversity_rate_rel" "water_rate_abs"        "water_rate_rel"

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Visualize indicator evolution across periods. Carbon stock evolution (2015-2025) Multiple indicator trends
code: # Carbon trends over time plot_temporal_trend(   temporal_data,   indicator = "carbon",   title = "Carbon Stock Evolution (2015-2025)" ) # Multiple indicators plot_temporal_trend(   temporal_data,   indicator = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   title = "Multi-Indicator Temporal Trends" )

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Heatmaps show spatial-temporal patterns (parcels Ã— periods). Heatmaps help identify: Indicator patterns: indicators changing together Temporal anomalies: Unexpected changes specific periods Parcel profiles: Quick visualization multi-indicator evolution
code: # Multi-indicator heatmap for a single parcel plot_temporal_heatmap(   temporal_data,   unit_id = "P001",   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   title = "Multi-Indicator Evolution - Parcel P001" )

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
code: # Scenario: Selective thinning in 2020 affects carbon and biodiversity  # Before intervention (2015) units_before <- massif_demo_units[1:5, ] units_before$parcel_id <- paste0("P", 1:5) units_before$carbon <- c(120, 135, 128, 142, 138) units_before$biodiversity <- c(10, 11, 9, 12, 10)  # After intervention (2025) - thinning increases biodiversity, reduces carbon short-term units_after <- massif_demo_units[1:5, ] units_after$parcel_id <- paste0("P", 1:5) units_after$carbon <- c(110, 125, 118, 132, 128)       # -8% carbon units_after$biodiversity <- c(14, 15, 13, 16, 14)     # +40% biodiversity  # Create temporal object intervention <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list("2015" = units_before, "2025" = units_after),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  print(intervention) #> nemeton_temporal object #>   2 periods: 2015, 2025 #>   5 units tracked across periods #>   Date range: 2015-01-01 to 2025-01-01 #>   Indicators: surface_ha, carbon, biodiversity

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Intervention impact biodiversity
code:
# Calculate change rates intervention_rates <- calculate_change_rate(   intervention,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity"),   type = "both" )  # Summary cat("
=== Intervention Impact Summary ===
") #>  #> === Intervention Impact Summary === cat("
Carbon change (absolute):
") #>  #> Carbon change (absolute): summary(intervention_rates$carbon_rate_abs) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #> -0.9999 -0.9999 -0.9999 -0.9999 -0.9999 -0.9999  cat("
Biodiversity change (absolute):
") #>  #> Biodiversity change (absolute): summary(intervention_rates$biodiversity_rate_abs) #>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>  0.3999  0.3999  0.3999  0.3999  0.3999  0.3999  # Trade-off analysis tradeoff <- intervention_rates %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%   select(parcel_id, carbon_rate_abs, biodiversity_rate_abs)  cat("
Trade-off Analysis:
") #>  #> Trade-off Analysis: print(tradeoff) #>   parcel_id carbon_rate_abs biodiversity_rate_abs #> 1        P1      -0.9998631             0.3999453 #> 2        P2      -0.9998631             0.3999453 #> 3        P3      -0.9998631             0.3999453 #> 4        P4      -0.9998631             0.3999453 #> 5        P5      -0.9998631             0.3999453 # Visualize biodiversity increase plot_temporal_trend(   intervention,   indicator = "biodiversity",   title = "Biodiversity Response to Thinning Intervention" )

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Combine temporal analysis multi-family system (see vignette("indicator-families")).
code: # Example workflow (requires family indicators computed)  # Compute family indicators for each period layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Period 1 results_2015 <- nemeton_compute(   units_2015,   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3") )  # Period 2 results_2020 <- nemeton_compute(   units_2020,   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3") )  # Create family indices for each period family_2015 <- create_family_index(results_2015) family_2020 <- create_family_index(results_2020)  # Temporal analysis of family scores temporal_families <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list("2015" = family_2015, "2020" = family_2020),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  # Family score change rates family_rates <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_families,   indicators = c("family_C", "family_W"),   type = "both" )

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Normalize periods using first period reference:
code: # Extract first period data baseline <- temporal_data$periods[[1]]  # Normalize each period using baseline reference temporal_normalized <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = lapply(temporal_data$periods, function(period_data) {     normalize_indicators(       period_data,       indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),       method = "minmax",       reference_data = baseline  # Use baseline min/max     )   }),   id_column = "parcel_id" )  # All periods now normalized to baseline (0-100 scale)

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: Identify parcels unusual change patterns:
code:
# Calculate z-scores of change rates rates_zscore <- rates_absolute %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry() %>%   mutate(     carbon_zscore = scale(carbon_rate_abs)[, 1],     biodiversity_zscore = scale(biodiversity_rate_abs)[, 1]   )  # Flag anomalies (|z| > 2) anomalies <- rates_zscore %>%   filter(abs(carbon_zscore) > 2 | abs(biodiversity_zscore) > 2) %>%   select(parcel_id, carbon_zscore, biodiversity_zscore)  if (nrow(anomalies) > 0) {   cat("
Detected anomalies (|z| > 2):
")   print(anomalies) } else {   cat("
No anomalies detected (all |z| < 2)
") } #>  #> Detected anomalies (|z| > 2): #>   parcel_id carbon_zscore biodiversity_zscore #> 1      P003     -2.147385            1.168131

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
code: # Save as RDS for future analysis saveRDS(temporal_data, "results/temporal_data_2015_2025.rds")  # Load later temporal_data <- readRDS("results/temporal_data_2015_2025.rds")

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
code: # Export as GeoPackage sf::st_write(   rates_both,   "results/change_rates_2015_2025.gpkg",   delete_dsn = TRUE )  # Export as CSV (without geometry) rates_table <- rates_both %>%   sf::st_drop_geometry()  write.csv(   rates_table,   "results/change_rates_2015_2025.csv",   row.names = FALSE )

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
code: # Time-series plot p1 <- plot_temporal_trend(temporal_data, indicator = "carbon") ggsave("figures/carbon_trend_2015_2025.png", p1, width = 10, height = 6, dpi = 300)  # Heatmap p2 <- plot_temporal_heatmap(temporal_data, unit_id = "P001") ggsave("figures/multi_indicator_heatmap.png", p2, width = 10, height = 6, dpi = 300)

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: nemeton temporal analysis workflow enables: Multi-period management: Track indicators across 2+ time periods Change quantification: Calculate absolute relative rates Trend visualization: Time-series plots heatmaps Intervention assessment: Evaluate management impacts Integration: Combine multi-family system comprehensive analysis

title: Temporal Analysis with nemeton
text: nemeton_temporal(): Create multi-period datasets calculate_change_rate(): Compute absolute/relative change rates plot_temporal_trend(): Time-series line plots parcels plot_temporal_heatmap(): Multi-indicator heatmap single parcel

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Lâ€™analyse temporelle permet de suivre lâ€™Ã©volution des services Ã©cosystÃ©miques forestiers sur plusieurs pÃ©riodes. Cette vignette dÃ©montre comment utiliser le systÃ¨me nemeton_temporal() pour : Comparer les indicateurs Ã  diffÃ©rentes dates Calculer les taux de changement Visualiser les tendances temporelles DÃ©tecter les ruptures et transitions
code: library(nemeton) library(ggplot2)

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Le framework temporel repose sur : Datasets multi-dates : Plusieurs jeux de donnÃ©es spatiales pour diffÃ©rentes pÃ©riodes Alignement spatial : Correspondance des unitÃ©s spatiales entre pÃ©riodes Calcul de changements : Taux de variation, diffÃ©rences absolues Visualisation : Graphiques temporels, heatmaps, cartes de diffÃ©rence

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Exemple de structure pour 3 pÃ©riodes temporal_data <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "2015" = list(       units = units_2015,       layers = layers_2015     ),     "2020" = list(       units = units_2020,       layers = layers_2020     ),     "2025" = list(       units = units_2025,       layers = layers_2025     )   ),   unit_id = "parcel_id"  # Colonne identifiant les parcelles )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Charger les donnÃ©es de base data(massif_demo_units) layers_2020 <- massif_demo_layers()  # Simuler des donnÃ©es pour 2015 et 2025 (pour la dÃ©mo) # En pratique, vous chargerez vos vrais datasets historiques  # CrÃ©er le dataset temporel temporal <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "2015" = list(units = massif_demo_units, layers = layers_2020),     "2020" = list(units = massif_demo_units, layers = layers_2020),     "2025" = list(units = massif_demo_units, layers = layers_2020)   ),   unit_id = "parcel_id" )  print(temporal)

what: Calculer les indicateurs pour chaque pÃ©riode
title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: RÃ©sultat : Un objet nemeton_temporal contenant les indicateurs calculÃ©s pour chaque pÃ©riode.
code: # Calculer automatiquement pour toutes les pÃ©riodes temporal_results <- nemeton_compute(   temporal,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water") )  # Afficher la structure summary(temporal_results)

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: InterprÃ©tation : - Taux > 0 : Augmentation - Taux < 0 : Diminution - Taux en %/
code: # Calculer le taux de changement annuel (%) change_rates <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   period_start = "2015",   period_end = "2025" )  # Afficher les taux de changement head(change_rates[, c("parcel_id", "carbon_rate", "biodiversity_rate", "water_rate")])

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Calculer les diffÃ©rences entre 2020 et 2025 differences <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_results,   indicators = "carbon",   period_start = "2020",   period_end = "2025",   method = "absolute"  # DiffÃ©rence absolue au lieu de taux )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Tendance pour une parcelle spÃ©cifique plot_temporal_trend(   temporal_results,   unit_id = "P01",   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   title = "Ã‰volution des indicateurs - Parcelle P01" )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Visualisation : Matrice colorÃ©e montrant lâ€™intensitÃ© de chaque indicateur par pÃ©riode et parcelle.
code: # Heatmap de tous les indicateurs sur toutes les pÃ©riodes plot_temporal_heatmap(   temporal_results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water", "fragmentation"),   title = "Heatmap temporelle - Tous indicateurs" )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Palette : Rouge (perte) â†’ Blanc (stable) â†’ Vert (gain)
code: # Carte montrant les changements de carbone 2015â†’2025 plot_difference_map(   temporal_results,   indicator = "carbon",   period_start = "2015",   period_end = "2025",   title = "Changement de stock carbone (2015-2025)",   legend_title = "Î” tC/ha" )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # 1. DÃ©finir les pÃ©riodes # - Avant intervention (2018) # - AprÃ¨s intervention (2020) # - Suivi Ã  5 ans (2025)  temporal_intervention <- nemeton_temporal(   periods = list(     "avant_2018" = list(units = units_avant, layers = layers_avant),     "apres_2020" = list(units = units_apres, layers = layers_apres),     "suivi_2025" = list(units = units_suivi, layers = layers_suivi)   ),   unit_id = "parcel_id" )  # 2. Calculer indicateurs results <- nemeton_compute(   temporal_intervention,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water", "fragmentation") )  # 3. Analyser les impacts impact_2020 <- calculate_change_rate(   results,   period_start = "avant_2018",   period_end = "apres_2020",   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity") )  recovery_2025 <- calculate_change_rate(   results,   period_start = "apres_2020",   period_end = "suivi_2025",   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity") )  # 4. Visualiser trajectoire plot_temporal_trend(   results,   unit_id = "PARCEL_INTERV_01",   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity"),   title = "Trajectoire post-intervention" )

what: Identifier les parcelles en changement rapide
title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Calculer taux de changement rates <- calculate_change_rate(   temporal_results,   indicators = "carbon",   period_start = "2015",   period_end = "2025" )  # Filtrer les parcelles avec forte dynamique high_change <- rates %>%   filter(abs(carbon_rate) > 2.0)  # > Â±2% par an  # Visualiser sur carte plot_indicators_map(   high_change,   indicators = "carbon_rate",   palette = "RdBu",   title = "Parcelles Ã  forte dynamique carbone",   legend_title = "Taux (%/an)" )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Classer les trajectoires rates <- rates %>%   mutate(     trajectory = case_when(       carbon_rate > 1.0 ~ "Forte augmentation",       carbon_rate > 0.2 ~ "Augmentation modÃ©rÃ©e",       abs(carbon_rate) <= 0.2 ~ "Stable",       carbon_rate > -1.0 ~ "Diminution modÃ©rÃ©e",       TRUE ~ "Forte diminution"     )   )  # Compter les trajectoires table(rates$trajectory)

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Avantage : Permet de comparer les rangs relatifs entre pÃ©riodes.
code: # Normaliser les indicateurs de chaque pÃ©riode sÃ©parÃ©ment temporal_norm <- normalize_indicators(   temporal_results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   method = "minmax",   by_period = TRUE  # Normalisation intra-pÃ©riode )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Avantage : Ã‰chelle commune pour toutes les pÃ©riodes.
code: # Normaliser sur toutes les pÃ©riodes ensemble temporal_norm_global <- normalize_indicators(   temporal_results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   method = "minmax",   by_period = FALSE  # Normalisation sur toutes les donnÃ©es )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # CrÃ©er indice composite pour chaque pÃ©riode composite_temporal <- create_composite_index(   temporal_norm,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.3, 0.3),   name = "ecosystem_quality" )  # Analyser l'Ã©volution de l'indice plot_temporal_trend(   composite_temporal,   unit_id = "P01",   indicators = "ecosystem_quality",   title = "Ã‰volution de la qualitÃ© Ã©cosystÃ©mique" )

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # CrÃ©er tableau rÃ©capitulatif summary_table <- temporal_results %>%   group_by(period) %>%   summarise(     carbon_mean = mean(carbon, na.rm = TRUE),     carbon_sd = sd(carbon, na.rm = TRUE),     biodiv_mean = mean(biodiversity, na.rm = TRUE),     biodiv_sd = sd(biodiversity, na.rm = TRUE)   )  print(summary_table)

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
code: # Export des taux de changement write.csv(   change_rates,   "results/temporal_change_rates.csv",   row.names = FALSE )  # Export cartes temporelles for (period in c("2015", "2020", "2025")) {   p <- plot_indicators_map(     temporal_results[[period]],     indicators = "carbon",     title = paste("Stock carbone -", period)   )   ggsave(     paste0("results/carbon_map_", period, ".png"),     p,     width = 8,     height = 6   ) }

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Assurer la correspondance spatiale entre pÃ©riodes (mÃªme emprise, mÃªmes parcelles) Utiliser un identifiant unique (unit_id) stable dans le temps VÃ©rifier les CRS (systÃ¨mes de coordonnÃ©es) identiques

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Intervalle minimum : 3-5 ans (dÃ©tecter changements significatifs) CohÃ©rence saisonniÃ¨re : mÃªmes dates dâ€™acquisition (Ã©viter biais phÃ©nologiques) Documentation des Ã©vÃ©nements : interventions, perturbations naturelles

title: Analyse temporelle - Suivi multi-pÃ©riodes
text: Taux < 0.5%/: Changement faible (potentiellement bruit) Taux 0.5-2%/: Changement modÃ©rÃ© (trajectoire naturelle) Taux > 2%/: Changement rapide (intervention ou perturbation)
