title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: Analyse systÃ©mique de territoires forestiers selon la mÃ©thode Nemeton nemeton est un package R pour lâ€™analyse intÃ©grÃ©e dâ€™Ã©cosystÃ¨mes forestiers Ã  partir de donnÃ©es spatiales ouvertes. Il implÃ©mente la mÃ©thode Nemeton pour calculer, normaliser et visualiser des indicateurs biophysiques multi-famille essentiels Ã  la gestion forestiÃ¨re durable.

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: ðŸŒ³ SystÃ¨me multi-famille : 12 familles dâ€™indicateurs (9 implÃ©mentÃ©es : C, B, W, , F, L, T, R + infrastructure) ðŸ“Š 25 sous-indicateurs : Carbone (C1-C2), BiodiversitÃ© (B1-B3), Eau (W1-W3), Air (A1-A2), Sols (F1-F2), Paysage (L1-L2), Temporel (T1-T2), Risques (R1-R3) + legacy â±ï¸ Analyse temporelle : Datasets multi-pÃ©riodes, calcul de taux de changement, visualisations ðŸ“ˆ Normalisation avancÃ©e : min-max, z-score, quantiles, par famille, avec rÃ©fÃ©rence ðŸŽ¯ AgrÃ©gation flexible : 5 mÃ©thodes (moyenne, pondÃ©rÃ©e, gÃ©omÃ©trique, harmonique, min) ðŸ—ºï¸ Visualisations riches : Cartes, radar multi-famille (jusquâ€™Ã  12 axes), comparaisons, tendances temporelles ðŸ”„ Workflow intÃ©grÃ© : De la donnÃ©e brute aux indices composites ðŸ“¦ Production-ready : 845+ tests, >70% coverage, 100% backward compatible

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: R â‰¥ 4.1.0 Packages spatiaux : sf, terra, exactextractr Visualisation : ggplot2, tidyr

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: # Depuis GitHub (version dÃ©veloppement) # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("pobsteta/nemeton")

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: library(nemeton)  # Charger le dataset de dÃ©monstration (136 ha, 20 parcelles forestiÃ¨res) data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # 1. CrÃ©er des indicateurs synthÃ©tiques multi-famille units <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ] units$C1 <- rnorm(10, 150, 20)  # Biomasse carbone units$C2 <- runif(10, 0.7, 0.9) # NDVI units$W1 <- rnorm(10, 0.8, 0.2) # RÃ©seau hydro units$W2 <- runif(10, 5, 15)    # Zones humides units$W3 <- rnorm(10, 8, 2)     # TWI  # 2. Normaliser par famille normalized <- normalize_indicators(units, method = "minmax", by_family = TRUE)  # 3. CrÃ©er indices de famille family_scores <- create_family_index(   normalized,   method = "weighted",   weights = list(     C = c(C1 = 0.7, C2 = 0.3),     W = c(W1 = 0.3, W2 = 0.3, W3 = 0.4)   ) )  # 4. Visualiser profil multi-famille (v0.3.0: support 9-12 familles) nemeton_radar(family_scores, unit_id = 1, mode = "family")  # Comparer plusieurs unitÃ©s (v0.3.0) nemeton_radar(family_scores, unit_id = c(1, 2, 3), mode = "family")

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: # Toujours fonctionnel pour compatibilitÃ© arriÃ¨re results <- nemeton_compute(massif_demo_units, layers, indicators = "all") normalized <- normalize_indicators(results, method = "minmax") health <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   name = "ecosystem_health" ) plot_indicators_map(health, indicators = "ecosystem_health", palette = "RdYlGn")

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: library(nemeton) library(sf)  # 1ï¸âƒ£ CrÃ©er les unitÃ©s d'analyse spatiales units <- nemeton_units(   "parcelles.gpkg",   metadata = list(     site_name = "ForÃªt de Fontainebleau",     year = 2024,     source = "IGN BD ForÃªt v2"   ) )  # 2ï¸âƒ£ CrÃ©er le catalogue de couches spatiales layers <- nemeton_layers(   rasters = list(     biomass = "data/biomass_agb.tif",      # Biomasse aÃ©rienne (Mg/ha)     dem = "data/ign_mnt_25m.tif",          # MNT 25m     landcover = "data/oso_landcover.tif"   # Occupation du sol   ),   vectors = list(     roads = "data/bdtopo_routes.gpkg",     # Routes     water = "data/bdtopo_hydro.gpkg"       # Cours d'eau   ) )  # 3ï¸âƒ£ Calculer les indicateurs (avec prÃ©processing automatique) results <- nemeton_compute(   units,   layers,   indicators = "all",  # Tous les indicateurs   preprocess = TRUE    # Harmonisation CRS + crop automatique )  # 4ï¸âƒ£ Normaliser les valeurs (Ã©chelle 0-100) normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "minmax" )  # 5ï¸âƒ£ CrÃ©er un indice de santÃ© Ã©cosystÃ©mique health_index <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2),   name = "ecosystem_health" )  # 6ï¸âƒ£ Visualiser sur une carte plot_indicators_map(   health_index,   indicators = "ecosystem_health",   palette = "RdYlGn",   title = "Indice de SantÃ© Ã‰cosystÃ©mique" )  # 7ï¸âƒ£ Sauvegarder ggsave("ecosystem_health.png", width = 10, height = 8, dpi = 300)

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: Le package inclut massif_demo, un dataset synthÃ©tique reprÃ©sentant un massif forestier de 136 ha avec 20 parcelles.

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: # Charger les unitÃ©s spatiales (parcelles) data(massif_demo_units) print(massif_demo_units) # 20 parcelles forestiÃ¨res en Lambert-93 (EPSG:2154)  # Charger les couches environnementales layers <- massif_demo_layers() summary(layers) # 4 rasters : biomass, dem, landcover, species_richness # 2 vecteurs : roads, water

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: 20 parcelles forestiÃ¨res (surface totale : 136 ha) Projection : Lambert-93 (EPSG:2154) RÃ©solution rasters : 25m biomass : Biomasse aÃ©rienne (Mg/ha) dem : ModÃ¨le NumÃ©rique de Terrain (m) landcover : Occupation du sol (classes 1-5) species_richness : Richesse spÃ©cifique (nb espÃ¨ces) roads : RÃ©seau routier (5 routes) water : Cours dâ€™eau (3 riviÃ¨res)

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: library(nemeton)  # 1. Analyse complÃ¨te data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers() results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "all",   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3) )  # 2. Visualiser les indicateurs bruts plot_indicators_map(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   palette = "viridis",   facet = TRUE,   ncol = 3 )  # 3. CrÃ©er un indice composite normalized <- normalize_indicators(results, method = "minmax") health <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm", "fragmentation_norm"),   weights = c(0.3, 0.3, 0.2, 0.2),   name = "ecosystem_health" )  # 4. Visualiser l'indice plot_indicators_map(   health,   indicators = "ecosystem_health",   palette = "RdYlGn",   title = "SantÃ© Ã‰cosystÃ©mique - Massif Demo" )

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: Stock de carbone forestier Ã  partir de biomasse aÃ©rienne. DonnÃ©es requises : Raster de biomasse (tonnes/ha ou Mg/ha) Source recommandÃ©e : Copernicus Biomass, GEDI, ou modÃ¨les locaux
code: # Exemple avec massif_demo data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers() carbon <- indicator_carbon(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   biomass_layer = "biomass",   conversion_factor = 0.47  # IPCC default ) summary(carbon)  # Stock de carbone en Mg C/ha

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: Indices de diversitÃ© (richesse, Shannon, Simpson). DonnÃ©es requises : Raster de richesse spÃ©cifique ou indices prÃ©-calculÃ©s Source recommandÃ©e : INPN, GBIF, inventaires forestiers
code: # Exemple avec massif_demo biodiv <- indicator_biodiversity(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   richness_layer = "species_richness",   index = "richness" ) summary(biodiv)  # Nombre moyen d'espÃ¨ces par parcelle

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: RÃ©gulation hydrique (TWI + proximitÃ© cours dâ€™eau). DonnÃ©es requises : MNT (DEM) + vecteur rÃ©seau hydrographique Source recommandÃ©e : IGN RGE ALTI, BD TOPO Hydrographie
code: # Exemple avec massif_demo water <- indicator_water(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   dem_layer = "dem",   water_layer = "water",   weights = c(0.6, 0.4) ) summary(water)  # Indice 0-1 (0 = faible, 1 = fort)

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
text: Fragmentation forestiÃ¨re (couverture, connectivitÃ©). DonnÃ©es requises : Raster dâ€™occupation du sol Source recommandÃ©e : OSO (Theia), Corine Land Cover
code: # Exemple avec massif_demo frag <- indicator_fragmentation(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   landcover_layer = "landcover",   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3)  # Classes forestiÃ¨res ) summary(frag)  # Pourcentage de couverture forestiÃ¨re

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: library(nemeton)  # 1ï¸âƒ£ Charger les donnÃ©es de dÃ©monstration data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # 2ï¸âƒ£ Calculer tous les indicateurs results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "all",   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3),  # Classes forestiÃ¨res pour fragmentation   progress = TRUE )  # 3ï¸âƒ£ Normaliser (Ã©chelle 0-100) normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "minmax" )  # 4ï¸âƒ£ CrÃ©er des indices composites ecosystem_health <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2),   name = "ecosystem_health" )  wilderness_index <- normalized %>%   invert_indicator(indicators = "accessibility_norm", suffix = "_wilderness") %>%   create_composite_index(     indicators = c("biodiversity_norm", "accessibility_norm_wilderness"),     weights = c(0.6, 0.4),     name = "wilderness"   )  # 5ï¸âƒ£ Visualiser plot_indicators_map(   ecosystem_health,   indicators = "ecosystem_health",   palette = "RdYlGn",   title = "SantÃ© Ã‰cosystÃ©mique" )  plot_indicators_map(   wilderness_index,   indicators = "wilderness",   palette = "Greens",   title = "Indice de Sauvagerie" )

code: # MÃ©thode 1 : Min-max (0-100, par dÃ©faut) normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   method = "minmax" )  # MÃ©thode 2 : Z-score (standardisation) normalized_z <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "zscore" )  # MÃ©thode 3 : Quantiles (robuste aux outliers) normalized_q <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "quantile" )  # Normalisation avec donnÃ©es de rÃ©fÃ©rence new_normalized <- normalize_indicators(   new_data,   reference_data = baseline_data,  # Utilise min/max de baseline   method = "minmax" )

title: nemeton - Analyse SystÃ©mique ForestiÃ¨re
code: # Indice de santÃ© Ã©cosystÃ©mique (pondÃ©ration Ã©gale) ecosystem <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   name = "ecosystem_health" )  # Indice de conservation (pondÃ©ration personnalisÃ©e) conservation <- create_composite_index(   normalized,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.3, 0.5, 0.2),  # PrioritÃ© biodiversitÃ©   name = "conservation_value" )  # Indice de sauvagerie (inverser accessibilitÃ©) wilderness <- normalized %>%   invert_indicator(     indicators = "accessibility_norm",     suffix = "_wilderness"   ) %>%   create_composite_index(     indicators = c("biodiversity_norm", "accessibility_norm_wilderness"),     weights = c(0.6, 0.4),     name = "wilderness_index"   )  # Approche conservatrice (facteur limitant) - v0.3.0 limiting <- create_family_index(   normalized,   method = "min"  # Prend la valeur minimale par famille )

title: Compute Correlation Matrix Between Family Indices â€” compute_family_correlations
text: Correlation matrix (class "matrix") family names row/column names

title: Compute Correlation Matrix Between Family Indices â€” compute_family_correlations
text: function computes pairwise correlations selected family indices reveal ecological relationships: - **Positive correlations** suggest synergies (e.g., Biodiversity Ã— Age) - **Negative correlations** indicate trade-offs (e.g., Protection Ã— Risk) - **Near-zero correlations** show independence Missing values (NA) handled using pairwise complete observations.

title: Compute Correlation Matrix Between Family Indices â€” compute_family_correlations
text: function supports bilingual messages via `nemeton_set_language()`.

title: Compute Correlation Matrix Between Family Indices â€” compute_family_correlations
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load demo data with family indices data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units units$family_B <- runif(nrow(units), 30, 90) units$family_T <- runif(nrow(units), 40, 85) units$family_C <- runif(nrow(units), 45, 80)  # Compute correlation matrix corr_matrix <- compute_family_correlations(units) print(corr_matrix)  # Use Spearman for non-linear relationships corr_spearman <- compute_family_correlations(units, method = "spearman")  # Analyze specific families only corr_subset <- compute_family_correlations(   units,   families = c("family_B", "family_T") ) } # }

what: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
title: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
text: Aggregates normalized indicators single composite score.

title: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
code: create_composite_index(   data,   indicators,   weights = NULL,   name = "composite_index",   aggregation = c("weighted_mean", "geometric_mean", "min", "max"),   na.rm = TRUE,   scale_to_100 = NULL )

title: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
text: data sf object data.frame normalized indicators indicators Character vector indicator column names include weights Numeric vector weights indicator (length indicators). NULL, equal weights used. Weights automatically normalized sum 1. name Character. Name composite index column. Default "composite_index". aggregation Character. Aggregation method. Options: "weighted_mean" - Weighted arithmetic mean (default) "geometric_mean" - Weighted geometric mean (good multiplicative effects) "min" - Minimum value (conservative, limiting factor approach) "max" - Maximum value (optimistic) na.rm Logical. Remove NA values aggregation? Default TRUE. scale_to_100 Logical. Scale result 0-100? Default TRUE weighted_mean, FALSE otherwise.

title: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
text: input data added composite index column

title: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
text: composite index combines multiple normalized indicators single score. Aggregation methods: Weighted mean: Standard linear combination, assumes indicators contribute additively Geometric mean: Better indicators multiplicative relationships Min: Conservative approach, final score limited weakest indicator Max: Optimistic approach, final score driven strongest indicator Weights normalized internally sum 1. example: weights = c(2, 1, 1) becomes c(0.5, 0.25, 0.25)

title: Create composite index from multiple indicators â€” create_composite_index
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Equal weights results <- create_composite_index(   normalized_data,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm") )  # Custom weights (carbon 50%, biodiversity 30%, water 20%) results <- create_composite_index(   normalized_data,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   weights = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2),   name = "ecosystem_health" )  # Geometric mean for multiplicative effects results <- create_composite_index(   normalized_data,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "water_norm"),   aggregation = "geometric_mean" )  # Limiting factor approach results <- create_composite_index(   normalized_data,   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm"),   aggregation = "min",   name = "conservation_potential" ) } # }

what: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
title: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
text: Aggregates sub-indicators family-level composite scores (e.g., score_carbon, score_water). Automatically detects indicator families column name prefixes (C_, W_, F_, L_, etc.) computes weighted averages.

title: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
code: create_family_index(   data,   method = c("mean", "weighted", "geometric", "harmonic", "min"),   weights = NULL,   na.rm = TRUE,   family_codes = NULL )

title: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
text: data sf object containing indicator columns family prefixes. method Character. Aggregation method: "mean", "weighted", "geometric", "harmonic", "min" (v0.3.0+). Default "mean". weights Named list weight vectors per family. E.g., list(C = c(C1 = 0.6, C2 = 0.4), W = c(W1 = 0.5, W2 = 0.3, W3 = 0.2)). NULL, equal weights used. na.rm Logical. TRUE, NA values removed aggregation. Default TRUE. family_codes Character vector. Family codes process. Default NULL (auto-detect).

title: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
text: input sf object added family_* columns (e.g., family_C, family_W).

title: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
text: **Family Detection**: Automatically identifies indicators prefix: C1, C2 -> Carbon family (family_C) W1, W2, W3 -> Water family (family_W) F1, F2 -> Soil fertility family (family_F) L1, L2 -> Landscape family (family_L) B1, B2, B3 -> Biodiversity family (family_B) 7 families (, T, R, S, P, E, N) **Aggregation Methods**: mean: Simple arithmetic mean weighted: Weighted average using provided weights geometric: Geometric mean (product^(1/n)) harmonic: Harmonic mean (n / sum(1/x)) min: Minimum value (worst-case, conservative) - v0.3.0+

title: Create Family Composite Indices â€” create_family_index
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Setup multi-family indicators data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units[1:5, ] units$C1 <- rnorm(5, 50, 10)  # Carbon biomass units$C2 <- rnorm(5, 70, 10)  # Carbon NDVI units$W1 <- rnorm(5, 15, 5)   # Water network  # Create family indices units_fam <- create_family_index(units)  # With custom weights units_fam <- create_family_index(   units,   weights = list(C = c(C1 = 0.7, C2 = 0.3)) ) } # }

title: Calculate accessibility indicator â€” indicator_accessibility
text: accessibility indicator based proximity transportation infrastructure: Roads: Primary accessibility factor (default weight: 0.7) Trails: Secondary accessibility factor (default weight: 0.3) invert = TRUE, indicator represents remoteness (useful wilderness/conservation contexts low accessibility desirable).

title: Calculate accessibility indicator â€” indicator_accessibility

what: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
title: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
text: Computes forest coverage percentage within buffer around parcel assess local air quality microclimate regulation potential.

title: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
code: indicator_air_coverage(   units,   land_cover,   forest_classes = c(311, 312, 313),   buffer_radius = 1000 )

title: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
text: units sf object forest parcels. land_cover SpatRaster land cover classification. forest_classes Numeric vector. Land cover class codes forests (e.g., Corine codes 311, 312, 313). Default c(311, 312, 313). buffer_radius Numeric. Buffer radius meters. Default 1000.

title: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
text: input sf object added column: A1: Forest coverage percentage (0-100) within buffer.

title: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
text: **Formula**: A1 = (forest_area_in_buffer / total_buffer_area) Ã— 100 **Interpretation**: 0-20%: Low forest coverage (poor air quality regulation) 20-50%: Moderate forest coverage 50-80%: Good forest coverage 80-100%: Excellent forest coverage (optimal air quality)

title: Calculate Tree Coverage Buffer Index (A1) â€” indicator_air_coverage
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton) library(terra)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ]  land_cover <- rast("path/to/corine_land_cover.tif")  # Calculate A1 with 1km buffer result <- indicator_air_coverage(units, land_cover = land_cover, buffer_radius = 1000) summary(result$A1)  # Calculate with 500m buffer result <- indicator_air_coverage(units, land_cover = land_cover, buffer_radius = 500) } # }

what: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
title: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
text: Computes air quality score using direct ATMO station data (available) proxy method based distance pollution sources (roads, urban areas).

title: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
code: indicator_air_quality(   units,   atmo_data = NULL,   roads = NULL,   urban_areas = NULL,   method = "auto" )

title: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
text: units sf object forest parcels. atmo_data sf object ATMO air quality stations (points). Must contain columns: NO2 (Âµg/mÂ³), PM10 (Âµg/mÂ³). Can NULL. roads sf object road network (lines). Used proxy method. urban_areas sf object urban zones (polygons). Used proxy method. method Character. Method use: "auto" (default): Use direct atmo_data available, else proxy "direct": Require ATMO data (error NULL) "proxy": Use distance-based proxy

title: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
text: input sf object added columns: A2: Air quality index (0-100). Higher = better air quality. A2_method: Method used ("direct" "proxy")

title: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
text: **Direct Method** (ATMO data): - Interpolate NO2 PM10 nearest stations - Convert quality score: low pollution = high score **Proxy Method** (distance-based): - Calculate distance nearest road urban area - Far pollution sources = high score

title: Calculate Air Quality Index (A2) â€” indicator_air_quality
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ]  # Direct method with ATMO data atmo_data <- st_read("path/to/atmo_stations.gpkg") result <- indicator_air_quality(units, atmo_data = atmo_data, method = "direct")  # Proxy method roads <- st_read("path/to/roads.gpkg") urban <- st_read("path/to/urban_areas.gpkg") result <- indicator_air_quality(units, roads = roads, urban_areas = urban, method = "proxy") } # }

Default "mean". ... Additional arguments (used)

title: Calculate Ecological Connectivity (B3) â€” indicator_biodiversity_connectivity
text: Computes distance forest parcel nearest ecological corridor (Trame Verte et Bleue).

title: Calculate Ecological Connectivity (B3) â€” indicator_biodiversity_connectivity
code: indicator_biodiversity_connectivity(   units,   corridors = NULL,   distance_method = c("edge", "centroid"),   max_distance = 5000 )

title: Calculate Ecological Connectivity (B3) â€” indicator_biodiversity_connectivity
text: units sf object forest parcels. corridors sf object ecological corridors (lines polygons). NULL, uses fallback scoring (default medium score 50). Default NULL. distance_method Character. Method distance calculation: "edge" (edge--edge), "centroid" (centroid--centroid). Default "edge". max_distance Numeric. Maximum distance threshold (meters). Distances beyond capped. Default 5000.

title: Calculate Ecological Connectivity (B3) â€” indicator_biodiversity_connectivity
text: input sf object added columns: B3: Distance nearest corridor (meters). Lower = better connectivity. B3_norm: Normalized connectivity score (0-100). Higher = better (inverse distance).

title: Calculate Ecological Connectivity (B3) â€” indicator_biodiversity_connectivity
text: **Calculation**: B3 = min distance corridor **Normalization**: B3_norm = 100 Ã— (1 - min(B3, max_distance) / max_distance) **Interpretation**: 0-500m: Excellent connectivity (B3_norm > 90) 500-1500m: Good connectivity (B3_norm 70-90) 1500-3000m: Fair connectivity (B3_norm 40-70) >3000m: Poor connectivity (B3_norm < 40)

title: Calculate Ecological Connectivity (B3) â€” indicator_biodiversity_connectivity
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton) library(sf)  data(massif_demo_units)  # Load ecological corridors (Trame Verte et Bleue) corridors <- st_read("trame_verte.gpkg")  result <- indicator_biodiversity_connectivity(   massif_demo_units,   corridors = corridors,   distance_method = "edge",   max_distance = 3000 )  # Highly connected parcels well_connected <- result[result$B3 < 500, ] } # }

title: Calculate Protected Area Coverage (B1) â€” indicator_biodiversity_protection
text: units sf object forest parcels (POLYGON MULTIPOLYGON). protected_areas sf object protected area polygons. NULL source="wfs", attempt fetch INPN WFS service. source Character. Data source: "local" (use protected_areas parameter) "wfs" (fetch INPN). Default "local". protection_types Character vector. Types protected areas include using WFS. Default c("ZNIEFF1", "ZNIEFF2", "N2000_SCI"). preprocess Logical. TRUE, harmonize CRS automatically. Default TRUE.

title: Calculate Protected Area Coverage (B1) â€” indicator_biodiversity_protection

title: Calculate Protected Area Coverage (B1) â€” indicator_biodiversity_protection
text: **Calculation**: B1 = (area_protected / area_total) Ã— 100 **Interpretation**: Higher values indicate better protection status. Parcels B1 > 75

title: Calculate Protected Area Coverage (B1) â€” indicator_biodiversity_protection
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton) library(sf)  # Load demo data data(massif_demo_units)  # Option A: Use local protected area data protected_zones <- st_read("path/to/protected_areas.shp") result <- indicator_biodiversity_protection(   massif_demo_units,   protected_areas = protected_zones,   source = "local" )  # Option B: Fetch from INPN WFS (requires internet) result <- indicator_biodiversity_protection(   massif_demo_units,   source = "wfs",   protection_types = c("ZNIEFF1", "ZNIEFF2", "N2000_SCI") )  # View results summary(result$B1) } # }

title: Calculate Structural Diversity (B2) â€” indicator_biodiversity_structure
text: Computes forest structural diversity using Shannon diversity index applied canopy strata age class distributions.

title: Calculate Structural Diversity (B2) â€” indicator_biodiversity_structure
code: indicator_biodiversity_structure(   units,   strata_field = "strata",   age_class_field = "age_class",   species_field = NULL,   method = "shannon",   weights = c(strata = 0.4, age = 0.3, species = 0.3),   use_height_cv = FALSE )

title: Calculate Structural Diversity (B2) â€” indicator_biodiversity_structure
text: units sf object forest parcels. strata_field Character. Column name containing canopy strata classes (e.g., "Emergent", "Dominant", "Intermediate", "Suppressed"). age_class_field Character. Column name containing age classes (e.g., "young", "mature", "old", "ancient"). species_field Character. Optional column name containing species names. NULL, species diversity included calculation. Default NULL. method Character. Diversity calculation method. Currently "shannon" supported. weights Named numeric vector. Weights strata, age, species components. Default c(strata = 0.4, age = 0.3, species = 0.3). use_height_cv Logical. TRUE strata_field NULL, use coefficient variation height proxy vertical diversity. Default FALSE.

title: Calculate Structural Diversity (B2) â€” indicator_biodiversity_structure
text: input sf object added column: B2: Structural diversity index (0-100). Higher = diverse.

title: Calculate Structural Diversity (B2) â€” indicator_biodiversity_structure
text: **Formula**: B2 = w1 Ã— H_strata_norm + w2 Ã— H_age_norm H Shannon diversity index, normalized 0-100 scale. **Interpretation**: Multi-layered, multi-age stands score high (>75). Monocultures even-aged stands score low (<25).

title: Calculate Structural Diversity (B2) â€” indicator_biodiversity_structure
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units  # Add structure attributes (normally from BD ForÃªt) units$strata <- sample(c("Emergent", "Dominant", "Intermediate"),                        nrow(units), replace = TRUE) units$age_class <- sample(c("Young", "Mature", "Old"),                           nrow(units), replace = TRUE)  result <- indicator_biodiversity_structure(   units,   strata_field = "strata",   age_class_field = "age_class",   species_field = "species" )  hist(result$B2, main = "Structural Diversity Distribution") } # }

what: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
title: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
text: Computes drought stress based topographic wetness (inverse TWI), precipitation deficit, species sensitivity.

title: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
code: indicator_risk_drought(   units,   twi_field = "W3",   climate = NULL,   species_field = "species",   weights = c(twi = 0.4, precip = 0.4, species = 0.2) )

title: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
text: units sf object forest parcels. twi_field Character. Column name Topographic Wetness Index (TWI). Can reuse W3 v0.2.0. climate List 'precipitation' SpatRaster, NULL. species_field Character. Column name species names. weights Named numeric vector. Weights components: c(twi, precip, species). Default c(0.4, 0.4, 0.2).

title: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
text: input sf object added column: R3: Drought stress (0-100). Higher = higher stress.

title: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
text: **Formula**: R3 = w1Ã—(100-TWI_norm) + w2Ã—precip_deficit + w3Ã—species_sensitivity **Components**: Inverse TWI: Low TWI (dry sites) = high drought stress Precipitation deficit: Low annual precip = high stress Species sensitivity: Fagus (80), Quercus (50), Pinus (50), others (50)

title: Calculate Drought Stress Index (R3) â€” indicator_risk_drought
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units  # Reuse W3 (TWI) from v0.2.0 units$W3 <- runif(nrow(units), 5, 15) units$species <- sample(c("Fagus", "Quercus", "Pinus"), nrow(units), replace = TRUE)  climate <- list(precipitation = rast("path/to/precip.tif"))  result <- indicator_risk_drought(units, twi_field = "W3", climate = climate, species_field = "species") summary(result$R3) } # }

title: Calculate Fire Risk Index (R1) â€” indicator_risk_fire
text: units sf object forest parcels. dem SpatRaster digital elevation model (meters). species_field Character. Column name species names. climate List 'temperature' 'precipitation' SpatRasters, NULL. weights Named numeric vector. Weights components: c(slope, species, climate). Default c(1/3, 1/3, 1/3).

title: Calculate Fire Risk Index (R1) â€” indicator_risk_fire
text: input sf object added column: R1: Fire risk index (0-100). Higher = higher risk.

title: Calculate Fire Risk Index (R1) â€” indicator_risk_fire
text: **Formula**: R1 = w1Ã—slope_factor + w2Ã—species_flammability + w3Ã—climate_dryness **Components**: slope_factor: Slope DEM, normalized 0-100 (>30Â° = max risk) species_flammability: Lookup internal table (Pinus=80, Quercus=50, Fagus=20) climate_dryness: Low precipitation + high temperature = high dryness

title: Calculate Fire Risk Index (R1) â€” indicator_risk_fire
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton) library(terra)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units units$species <- sample(c("Pinus", "Quercus", "Fagus"), nrow(units), replace = TRUE)  dem <- rast("path/to/dem.tif") climate <- list(   temperature = rast("path/to/temp.tif"),   precipitation = rast("path/to/precip.tif") )  result <- indicator_risk_fire(units, dem = dem, species_field = "species", climate = climate) summary(result$R1) } # }

title: Calculate Storm Vulnerability Index (R2) â€” indicator_risk_storm

what: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
title: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
text: Computes stand age direct age field establishment year, log-scale normalization favoring ancient forests.

title: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
code: indicator_temporal_age(   units,   age_field = "age",   establishment_year_field = NULL,   current_year = NULL )

title: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
text: units sf object forest parcels. age_field Character. Column name stand age (years). Default "age". establishment_year_field Character. Column name establishment year. Used age_field NULL. current_year Integer. Current year age calculation establishment year. Default uses current system year.

title: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
text: input sf object added columns: T1: Stand age (years) T1_norm: Normalized age score (0-100). Log scale, ancient forests score high.

title: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
text: **Formula**: T1 = age (direct) current_year - establishment_year **Normalization**: Log scale favor ancient forests 0-30 years: Young forest (0-30 score) 30-100 years: Mature forest (30-60 score) 100-200 years: Old forest (60-80 score) 200+ years: Ancient forest (80-100 score)

title: Calculate Stand Age Index (T1) â€” indicator_temporal_age
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units units$age <- runif(nrow(units), 20, 250)  result <- indicator_temporal_age(units, age_field = "age") summary(result$T1) summary(result$T1_norm)  # Using establishment year units$planted <- sample(1850:2000, nrow(units), replace = TRUE) result <- indicator_temporal_age(units, age_field = NULL, establishment_year_field = "planted", current_year = 2025) } # }

what: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
title: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
text: Computes annualized land cover change rate multi-date rasters (e.g., Corine Land Cover).

title: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
code: indicator_temporal_change(   units,   land_cover_early,   land_cover_late,   years_elapsed,   interpretation = "stability" )

title: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
text: units sf object forest parcels. land_cover_early SpatRaster early land cover classification. land_cover_late SpatRaster late land cover classification. years_elapsed Numeric. Number years two land cover dates. interpretation Character. interpret change: "stability" (default): Low change = high score (conservation) "dynamism": High change = high score (ecological dynamism)

title: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
text: input sf object added columns: T2: Annualized change rate (%/year) T2_norm: Normalized score (0-100). Depends interpretation.

title: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
text: **Formula**: T2 = (changed_pixels / total_pixels) / years_elapsed Ã— 100 **Normalization**: stability: 0% change/yr = 100, 5%+ change/yr = 0 dynamism: 0% change/yr = 0, 5%+ change/yr = 100

title: Calculate Land Cover Change Rate Index (T2) â€” indicator_temporal_change
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton) library(terra)  data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units[1:10, ]  lc_1990 <- rast("path/to/corine_1990.tif") lc_2020 <- rast("path/to/corine_2020.tif")  # Stability interpretation (conservation) result <- indicator_temporal_change(units, lc_1990, lc_2020, years_elapsed = 30, interpretation = "stability") summary(result$T2)  # Dynamism interpretation (ecological change) result <- indicator_temporal_change(units, lc_1990, lc_2020, years_elapsed = 30, interpretation = "dynamism") } # }

title: Calculate water regulation indicator â€” indicator_water
text: water regulation indicator combines two components: (1) Topographic Wetness Index (TWI) - Simplified proxy DEM slope; (2) Proximity water - Distance nearest water body (inverse weighted). MVP (v0.1.0), TWI approximated slope. Future versions implement full flow accumulation analysis.

code: # Load demo parcels and layers data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers() #> â„¹ Chargement des couches spatiales Massif Demo... #> â„¹ Created layer catalog: 4 rasters, 2 vectors #> âœ” 4 couches raster et 2 couches vecteur chargÃ©es  # Inspect layers print(layers) #>  #> â”€â”€ nemeton_layers object â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ #>  #> â”€â”€ Rasters (4) â”€â”€ #>  #> â€¢ biomass : massif_demo_biomass.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ dem : massif_demo_dem.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ landcover : massif_demo_landcover.tif [not loaded]  #> â€¢ species_richness : massif_demo_species_richness.tif [not loaded]  #>  #> â”€â”€ Vectors (2) â”€â”€ #>  #> â€¢ roads : massif_demo_roads.gpkg [not loaded]  #> â€¢ water : massif_demo_water.gpkg [not loaded]  #>   if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Compute all indicators results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "all",   preprocess = TRUE )  # Carbon indicator only carbon <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "carbon",   preprocess = TRUE )  # Water regulation (using DEM and water courses) water <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "water",   preprocess = TRUE )  # Fragmentation (using land cover) fragmentation <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units,   layers,   indicators = "fragmentation",   forest_values = c(1, 2, 3),  # Forest classes   preprocess = TRUE ) } # }

title: Massif Demo - Example Forest Dataset â€” massif_demo_units
text: sf object 20 features 5 fields: parcel_id Character. Unique parcel identifier (P01-P20) forest_type Character. Forest type: "Futaie feuillue" - Broadleaf high forest "Futaie rÃ©sineuse" - Coniferous high forest "Futaie mixte" - Mixed high forest "Taillis" - Coppice age_class Character. Stand age class: "Jeune" - Young (< 40 years) "Moyen" - Middle-aged (40-80 years) "Mature" - Mature (80-120 years) "SurannÃ©e" - -mature (> 120 years) management Character. Management objective: "Production" - Timber production "Conservation" - Biodiversity conservation "Mixte" - Mixed objectives surface_ha Numeric. Parcel area hectares geometry sfc_POLYGON. Parcel boundaries (EPSG:2154)

title: Massif Demo - Example Forest Dataset â€” massif_demo_units
text: Synthetic data generated data-raw/massif_demo.R

title: Massif Demo - Example Forest Dataset â€” massif_demo_units
text: dataset includes: **Parcels** (massif_demo_units): - 20 forest parcels (2-20 ha , 136 ha total) - Realistic spatial clustering irregular shapes - Diverse forest types management regimes **Rasters** (25m resolution, inst/extdata/): - massif_demo_biomass.tif: Aboveground biomass (50-400 Mg/ha) - massif_demo_dem.tif: Digital Elevation Model (350-700m) - massif_demo_landcover.tif: Land cover (6 classes, 85% forest) - massif_demo_species_richness.tif: Species richness (5-45 species) **Vector layers** (inst/extdata/): - massif_demo_roads.gpkg: 5 roads (types: DÃ©partementale, ForestiÃ¨re, Chemin) - massif_demo_water.gpkg: 3 water courses (types: Ruisseau, RiviÃ¨re, Torrent) spatial data use Lambert-93 projection (EPSG:2154). Generated set.seed(42) reproducibility.

title: Massif Demo - Example Forest Dataset â€” massif_demo_units
text: dataset created synthetically represent typical French forest landscapes: - Biomass: Spatial gradient patches noise - Topography: Realistic elevation gentle slopes - Land cover: Spatially coherent forest/non-forest classes - Species richness: Correlated biomass habitat diversity - Infrastructure: Sinuous roads topography-following streams

what: nemeton: Systemic Forest Analysis Using the Nemeton Method â€” nemeton-package
title: nemeton: Systemic Forest Analysis Using the Nemeton Method â€” nemeton-package
text: Implement Nemeton method systemic forest territory analysis. Calculate multi-family biophysical indicators across 12 ecosystem service families (carbon, water, soil, landscape, biodiversity, etc.), perform temporal analysis, normalize composite indices, visualize results. Designed foresters, ecologists, land managers. nemeton package implements Nemeton method comprehensive forest ecosystem analysis. provides tools calculate, normalize, visualize multi-family biophysical indicators across 12 ecosystem service dimensions.

title: nemeton: Systemic Forest Analysis Using the Nemeton Method â€” nemeton-package
text: Multi-Family Indicator System: C - Carbon/Vitality: Biomass stock (C1), NDVI vitality (C2) W - Water: Network density (W1), wetlands (W2), TWI (W3) F - Soil Fertility: Fertility (F1), erosion risk (F2) L - Landscape: Fragmentation (L1), edge ratio (L2) B - Biodiversity: Planned v0.3.0+ R - Resilience/Risks: Planned v0.3.0+ Plus 6 additional families future versions Temporal Analysis: Multi-period dataset management Change rate calculations (absolute relative) Time-series heatmap visualizations /intervention comparison Normalization & Aggregation: 3 normalization methods: minmax, zscore, quantile 4 aggregation methods: mean, weighted, geometric, harmonic Family-level composite indices Reference-based normalization temporal consistency Visualization: Spatial maps (single faceted) Multi-family radar plots (4-12 axes) Temporal trend plots Multi-indicator heatmaps Comparison difference maps

title: nemeton: Systemic Forest Analysis Using the Nemeton Method â€” nemeton-package
text: See vignettes comprehensive guides: vignette("getting-started", package = "nemeton") -     Introduction basic workflows demo data vignette("temporal-analysis", package = "nemeton") -     Multi-period analysis change detection vignette("indicator-families", package = "nemeton") -     Complete reference 12-family system vignette("internationalization", package = "nemeton") -     Bilingual support (French/English)

title: nemeton: Systemic Forest Analysis Using the Nemeton Method â€” nemeton-package
code: library(nemeton)  # Load demo data data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers()  # Compute multi-family indicators results <- nemeton_compute(   massif_demo_units[1:10, ],   layers,   indicators = c("C1", "C2", "W1", "W2", "W3"),   preprocess = TRUE )  # Normalize by family normalized <- normalize_indicators(results, by_family = TRUE)  # Create family indices family_scores <- create_family_index(normalized)  # Visualize multi-family profile nemeton_radar(family_scores, unit_id = 1, mode = "family")

title: nemeton: Systemic Forest Analysis Using the Nemeton Method â€” nemeton-package
text: Indicator Calculation: nemeton_compute - Compute biophysical indicators indicator_carbon_biomass - Carbon stock (C1) indicator_carbon_ndvi - Vegetation vitality (C2) indicator_water_network - Hydrographic density (W1) indicator_water_wetlands - Wetland coverage (W2) indicator_water_twi - Topographic Wetness Index (W3) indicator_soil_fertility - Soil fertility (F1) indicator_soil_erosion - Erosion risk (F2) indicator_landscape_fragmentation - Fragmentation (L1) indicator_landscape_edge - Edge ratio (L2) Temporal Analysis: nemeton_temporal - Multi-period dataset management calculate_change_rate - Change rate calculations plot_temporal_trend - Time-series plots plot_temporal_heatmap - Indicator evolution heatmaps Normalization & Aggregation: normalize_indicators - Scale indicators 0-100 create_family_index - Aggregate indicators family create_composite_index - Custom composite indices invert_indicator - Invert indicator direction Visualization: plot_indicators_map - Spatial maps nemeton_radar - Multi-family radar plots plot_comparison_map - Side--side comparison plot_difference_map - Change maps Data Management: massif_demo_units - Demo forest parcels dataset massif_demo_layers - Demo spatial layers

title: Calculate Nemeton indicators for spatial units â€” nemeton_compute
text: units nemeton_units sf object representing analysis units layers nemeton_layers object containing spatial data layers indicators Character vector indicator names calculate, "" available. Available indicators: "carbon", "biodiversity", "water", "fragmentation", "accessibility" preprocess Logical. Automatically harmonize CRS crop layers? Default TRUE. parallel Logical. Use parallel computation? (implemented MVP, error TRUE) progress Logical. Show progress bar? Default TRUE. ... Additional arguments passed indicator functions

title: Calculate Nemeton indicators for spatial units â€” nemeton_compute
text: sf object original columns plus one column per calculated indicator

title: Calculate Nemeton indicators for spatial units â€” nemeton_compute
text: function performs following steps: Validates inputs (units layers) preprocess = TRUE: Reprojects layers units CRS Crops layers units extent indicator: Calls corresponding indicator_*() function Handles errors gracefully (warning + NA column) Updates metadata Returns enriched sf object indicator calculation fails, warning issued indicator column filled NA, computation continues indicators.

title: Calculate Nemeton indicators for spatial units â€” nemeton_compute
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(nemeton)  # Create units units <- nemeton_units(sf::st_read("parcels.gpkg"))  # Create layer catalog layers <- nemeton_layers(   rasters = list(     biomass = "biomass.tif",     dem = "dem.tif"   ),   vectors = list(     roads = "roads.gpkg"   ) )  # Calculate all indicators results <- nemeton_compute(units, layers)  # Calculate specific indicators results <- nemeton_compute(   units, layers,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity") ) } # }

what: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar
title: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar

title: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar
code: nemeton_radar(   data,   unit_id = NULL,   indicators = NULL,   mode = c("indicator", "family"),   normalize = TRUE,   title = NULL,   fill_color = "#3182bd",   fill_alpha = 0.3 )

title: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar
text: data sf object indicator columns unit_id Optional. ID specific unit plot. Can single value vector IDs comparison mode (v0.3.0+). NULL, plots average units. indicators Character vector indicator names include radar. NULL, auto-detects based mode. mode Character. Display mode: "indicator" individual indicators (default) "family" family indices (family_C, family_W, etc.). mode = "family", supports 4-12 family axes dynamically. normalize Logical. TRUE (default), normalizes values 0-100 scale. title Optional plot title. NULL, auto-generated based unit_id. fill_color Color fill radar polygon. Default "#3182bd" (blue). fill_alpha Transparency fill (0-1). Default 0.3.

title: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar
text: ggplot object

title: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar
text: radar chart displays multiple indicators axes radiating center point. axis represents one indicator, values scaled center (0) edge (100). unit_id specified, chart shows profile specific unit. unit_id vector (v0.3.0+), creates comparison chart multiple overlaid polygons comparing units side--side. unit_id NULL, chart shows mean values across units. Normalization recommended indicators different scales. function applies min-max normalization scale values 0-100. **v0.3.0 Enhancements**: Supports 9-12 family axes comparison mode multiple units.

title: Create radar chart for indicator profile â€” nemeton_radar
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load demo data data(massif_demo_units) layers <- massif_demo_layers() results <- nemeton_compute(massif_demo_units, layers, indicators = "all") normalized <- normalize_indicators(results)  # Radar for a specific unit (indicator mode) nemeton_radar(normalized, unit_id = "unit_001")  # Radar for average of all units nemeton_radar(normalized)  # Custom indicators and styling nemeton_radar(   normalized,   unit_id = "unit_005",   indicators = c("carbon_norm", "biodiversity_norm", "water_norm"),   fill_color = "#d73027",   fill_alpha = 0.5 )  # Family mode with 9+ families (v0.3.0) # First create family indices units_fam <- create_family_index(normalized) nemeton_radar(units_fam, unit_id = 1, mode = "family")  # Comparison mode (v0.3.0) - compare multiple units nemeton_radar(units_fam, unit_id = c(1, 2, 3), mode = "family") } # }

title: Normalize indicator values â€” normalize_indicators
text: Transforms indicator values common scale comparison aggregation.

title: Normalize indicator values â€” normalize_indicators
code: normalize_indicators(   data,   indicators = NULL,   method = c("minmax", "zscore", "quantile"),   suffix = "_norm",   keep_original = TRUE,   na.rm = TRUE,   reference_data = NULL,   by_family = FALSE )

title: Normalize indicator values â€” normalize_indicators
text: data sf object data.frame containing indicator values indicators Character vector indicator column names normalize. NULL, auto-detects indicator columns. method Character. Normalization method. Options: "minmax" - Min-max normalization 0-100 scale (default) "zscore" - Z-score standardization (mean=0, sd=1) "quantile" - Quantile normalization (0-100 based percentile rank) suffix Character. Suffix add normalized column names. Default "_norm". keep_original Logical. Keep original indicator columns? Default TRUE. na.rm Logical. Remove NA values normalization? Default TRUE. reference_data Optional data.frame reference values normalization. Useful normalizing new data using parameters reference dataset. by_family Logical. TRUE, normalize indicators within family using family-wide parameters (e.g., Carbon indicators C1, C2 share min/max). makes indicators within family directly comparable. Default FALSE.

title: Normalize indicator values â€” normalize_indicators
text: input data added normalized columns

title: Normalize indicator values â€” normalize_indicators
text: Normalization methods: Min-max (0-100): norm = (value - min) / (max - min) * 100     - Preserves original distribution shape     - Sensitive outliers     - Interpretable scale (0 = worst, 100 = best) Z-score: norm = (value - mean) / sd     - Centers data around 0     - Units standard deviations     - Less sensitive outliers Quantile: norm = percentile_rank * 100     - Robust outliers     - Creates uniform distribution     - 0 = lowest percentile, 100 = highest

title: Normalize indicator values â€” normalize_indicators
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Normalize all indicators with min-max normalized <- normalize_indicators(   results,   indicators = c("carbon", "biodiversity", "water"),   method = "minmax" )  # Z-score normalization normalized_z <- normalize_indicators(   results,   method = "zscore",   suffix = "_z" )  # Normalize using reference dataset new_normalized <- normalize_indicators(   new_data,   indicators = c("carbon", "water"),   reference_data = reference_results ) } # }

title: Plot Correlation Matrix Heatmap â€” plot_correlation_matrix
text: corr_matrix Correlation matrix [compute_family_correlations()] method Display method: "circle" (default), "square", "number", "color" title Plot title. NULL, generates automatic title palette Color palette: "RdBu" (default, red-blue diverging) "viridis"

title: Plot Correlation Matrix Heatmap â€” plot_correlation_matrix
text: ggplot2 object

title: Plot Correlation Matrix Heatmap â€” plot_correlation_matrix
text: Creates publication-ready correlation heatmap : - Color intensity proportional correlation strength - Diverging palette (blue = negative, red = positive) - Correlation coefficients displayed cells - Hierarchical clustering (optional) **Interpretation**: - **Strong positive** (red, >0.5): Synergies (services co-occur) - **Strong negative** (blue, <-0.5): Trade-offs (services conflict) - **Weak** (white, ~0): Independence

title: Plot Correlation Matrix Heatmap â€” plot_correlation_matrix
text: function supports bilingual labels via `nemeton_set_language()`.

title: Plot Correlation Matrix Heatmap â€” plot_correlation_matrix
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Compute correlations data(massif_demo_units) units <- massif_demo_units units$family_B <- runif(nrow(units), 30, 90) units$family_T <- runif(nrow(units), 40, 85) units$family_C <- runif(nrow(units), 45, 80)  corr_matrix <- compute_family_correlations(units)  # Plot correlation heatmap plot_correlation_matrix(corr_matrix)  # Customize appearance plot_correlation_matrix(   corr_matrix,   method = "number",   title = "Ecosystem Service Synergies & Trade-offs" ) } # }

code: plot_indicators_map(   data,   indicators = NULL,   palette = c("viridis", "RdYlGn", "YlOrRd", "Greens", "Blues"),   direction = 1,   title = NULL,   legend_title = NULL,   breaks = NULL,   labels = NULL,   alpha = 0.9,   border_color = "white",   border_size = 0.3,   facet = TRUE,   ncol = 2,   base_size = 11 )

title: Create thematic maps for indicators â€” plot_indicators_map
text: data sf object indicator values indicators Character vector indicator column names plot. NULL multiple indicators present, creates faceted plot. palette Character. Color palette use. Options: "viridis" - Perceptually uniform, colorblind-friendly (default) "RdYlGn" - Red-Yellow-Green diverging (low-medium-high) "YlOrRd" - Yellow-Orange-Red sequential "Greens" - Green sequential "Blues" - Blue sequential direction Numeric. Direction color scale: 1 (default) -1 (reversed) title Character. Plot title. NULL, auto-generated. legend_title Character. Legend title. NULL, uses "Value" indicator name. breaks Numeric vector. Manual breaks color scale. NULL, automatic. labels Character vector. Labels breaks. length breaks. alpha Numeric. Transparency (0-1). Default 0.9. border_color Character. Border color polygons. Default "white". border_size Numeric. Border line width. Default 0.3. facet Logical. Create faceted plot multiple indicators? Default TRUE. ncol Integer. Number columns faceted plot. Default 2. base_size Numeric. Base font size theme. Default 11.

title: Create thematic maps for indicators â€” plot_indicators_map

title: nemeton 0.3.0 (Development)
text: Calculates percentage forest parcel within protected zones (ZNIEFF, Natura2000, etc.) Supports local remote protected area datasets Output: 0-100% protection coverage Spatial overlay area-weighted calculation Shannon diversity index across vegetation strata, age classes, species Configurable weights diversity component (default: strata 0.4, age 0.3, species 0.3) Optional height coefficient variation (CV) integration Output: 0-100 diversity score Handles monoculture scenarios (low diversity â†’ low scores) Distance ecological corridors (TVB - Trame Verte et Bleue) Supports edge centroid distance methods Configurable max distance threshold (default: 5000m) Fallback scoring corridor data unavailable Output: Distance meters (lower = better connectivity)

previous_headings: v0.3.0 MVP - Multi-Family Extension (B, R, T, A) > New Indicator Families
title: nemeton 0.3.0 (Development)
text: Multi-factor fire susceptibility: slope + species + climate Species flammability coefficients (conifer > broadleaf) Slope amplification (higher slope = faster fire spread) Optional climate data integration (temperature, precipitation) Output: 0-100 risk score (higher = vulnerable) Wind damage risk: tree height Ã— stand density Ã— exposure Height coefficient (taller trees vulnerable) Density factor (dense stands = higher windthrow risk) Topographic exposure DEM (exposed ridges = higher risk) Output: 0-100 vulnerability score Combines water availability (TWI) species drought tolerance Species tolerance coefficients (drought-resistant vs.Â water-demanding) Optional precipitation data integration Low TWI + intolerant species = high stress Output: 0-100 stress score

title: nemeton 0.2.0 (Development)
text: Calculates stream/river network length density within near forest parcels Supports buffer distance parameter proximity analysis Output: km/ha (kilometers watercourse per hectare) Higher values = greater hydrological connectivity Calculates percentage parcel area classified wetland riparian zone Supports multiple wetland type codes landcover rasters Output: 0-100% coverage Area-weighted calculation using coverage fractions Calculates TWI using terra D8 flow algorithm Formula: TWI = ln(catchment_area / tan(slope)) Automatically handles flat areas edge cases Output: TWI values (typically 0-20, higher = wetter areas) Future: whitebox D-infinity algorithm support (v0.3.0+)
